After a month of collaboration, they will be incorporated into the twelfth battalion of the territorial infantry of the national army.

The rebels left the city the following day.

The militiamen were recruited and armed by Wagner mercenaries and FACA forces, with whom they allied.

Wagner armed men destroyed several properties, severely injured 36 people and killed around 10 miners.

actor1: CPC: Coalition of Patriots for Change
assoc_actor_1: Anti-Balaka; RRR: Return, Reclamation and Rehabilitation; MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
notes: Change to armed group: On 19 December 2020, leaders of the 3 main armed rebel groups occupying large areas of CAR, namely the Anti-Balaka, 3R and MPC, announced a coalition, called the Coalition of Patriots for Change or CPC, ahead of the 27 December elections. The armed groups had decided 'to combine all of our movements into a single entity and under a unified command, and invited 'all other armed groups to join'. The groups accused President Faustin-Archange Touadera's government of seeking to fix upcoming elections and warned of a violent response. The coalition vowed not to attack civilians and to allow vehicles belonging to the United Nations and to humanitarian groups to circulate freely. Location is coded to Bangui (Bangui, Bangui).

actor1: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
actor2: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: On 6 August 2020, the Central African Republic Prime Minister signed an agreement in Bangui (Banui, Bangui) with the leader of the UPC (Union for Peace in the Central African Republic) armed group, Ali Darass. The latter committed not to hinder the return of state authority as well as the free movement of agents of the ANE (National Election Authority) before the upcoming election. In exchange, among other agreements, this armed group was allowed to return to Bambari (Ouaka), their former headquarters.

On 5 August 2020, the UN Security Council voted to impose sanctions on Sidiki Abbas, the leader of the 3R armed group (Return, Reclamation and Rehabilitation). The group, who withdrew from a peace agreement in June 2020, was accused of killing, torturing, raping and displacing civilians as well as engaging in arms trafficking and in war with other militias since its creation in 2015.

notes: On 29 April 2020, a large group of RPRC militiamen in coalition with MLCJ and PRNC, all of the Kara Ethnic Group, clashed with FPRC rebels, in control of the area and mostly of Ronga ethnicity, during an incursion in the centre of Ndele (Ndele, Bamingui-Bangoran). The FPRC, outnumbered, reportedly tried to fight the assailants and with MINUSCA support to protect civilians. The Government stated that 25 people were killed, including 21 civilians, while 51 were injured, but other sources reported at least 37 were killed.
On 28 April 2020, Anti-balaka armed men abducted a man in Gbama, 29 km from Bria (Haute-Kotto), accused of violating their leader's mining zone.

actor1: RPRC: Patriotic Movement for the Rebirth of the Central African People

On 26 April 2020, 3 Anti-Balaka militiamen robbed the base of the DRC (Danish Refugee Council) INGO in Batangafo (Ouham, Batangafo) and took away 1 computer and office material. The 3 robbers were later handed over to MINUSCA by their Anti-Balaka leader (Arnaud) for prosecution but escaped from the MINUSCA base.
On 26 April 2020, Anti-Balaka abducted a man in Bria (Haute-Kotto) accused of not paying a tax to this armed group. They released the man after he paid.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic

actor1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa

On 18 April 2020, Anti-Balaka armed men abducted a man in Bria (Haute-Kotto) and demanded money for his release. Civil society leaders intervened and secured the man's release after paying an amount of money.

On 6 April 2020, an LRA group abducted 15 boys to carry looted goods stolen from the community of Bougoua (Obo, Haut-Mbomou). They released the boys later that day. No fatalities and/or injuries reported, but the LRA group had been camped out in this area for 4 days.

On 6 April 2020, an LRA group armed with AK-47s and dressed in civilian attire, looted the community of Ligoua (Obo, Haut-Mbomou). Community members fled to Obo and alerted authorities. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

On 5 April 2020, an LRA group abducted a man travelling from Obo to Mboki, 8 km east of Kadjema (Obo, Haut-Mbomou). The assailants released the man after learning he was transporting goods for ex-Seleka (UPC) forces. No fatalities and/or injuries reported.

The aid workers were ambushed by armed men suspected to be MPC or FPRC, robbed, and assaulted. The aid workers and patients later managed to reach Batangafo where they received treatment at an INGO hospital.

actor1: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic

actor1: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
actor2: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)

On 1 July 2019, in Bangui, unidentified assailants vandalized Renaissance Party HQ destroying furniture and damaging facilities. The head of the new party, Augustin Agou, claims that the act is political.

assoc_actor_1: SYNAES: Autonomous Union of Higher Education Teachers; Teachers (Central African Republic); Students (Central African Republic)
notes: On 26 June 2019, in Bangui, an unspecified number of university teachers, SYNASES members and students, protested demanding 3 years of leave. The demonstration started at campus and moved along Bangui streets, temporary disrupting traffic. [size=no report]

On 25 June 2019, in Batangafo, 1 INGO staff member was assaulted and injured after anti-Balaka armed actors broke into his home. During the armed incursion, four others in the home were robbed of their mobile phones, cash, and other items. The staff member received medical treatment at a local hospital, and the perpetrators were handed over to MINUSCA by a local anti-Balaka leader.

assoc_actor_2: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: On 19 June 2019, in Bangui, unidentified men have attempted to kidnap minister of livestock of CAR. The victim has narrowly escaped.

On 18 June 2019, in Kpabou [coordinates are approximate based on CT map], an LRA group, comprised of women, children, and 7 armed men, looted a field. The group looted maize and peanuts. The assailants spoke Acholi and Zande, and were dressed in civilian and military attire. The group left heading east towards Mboki.

On 17 June 2019, an LRA group, comprised of men, women, and children looted field camps 10 km southeast of Mboki. The assailants looted cassava, maize and peanuts. They spoke Acholi, Zande, and broken Sango. Some were armed with AK-47s.

actor1: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: In June [coded to 15 June], 3 FACA soldiers have gang-raped and seriously injured a woman in Bozoum.

actor2: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
source: BBC News; RFI; AFP; Centrafrique Presse Info; aBangui; La Libre Afrique; Twitter
notes: On 15 June 2019, in Bangui, clashes of police with demonstrators during several thousand-strong demonstration. During the demonstration, two French journalists from AFP were brutally assaulted, arrested, and their equipment broken. [size=several thousand]
On 10 June 2019, in Obo, the LRA abducted 5 men. The victims had been forced to carry looted goods to the groups camp near the Mbomou River. The abductees were released by the LRA group on 13 June.

assoc_actor_2: Fulani Ethnic Group (Central African Republic); Pastoralists (Central African Republic); Farmers (Central African Republic)
notes: On 10 June 2019, a suspected LRA group, comprised of men, women, and children, attacked a Peuhl camp 4 km northwest of Obo. The assailants stole 4 cattle from the victims. They also looted a nearby field. The farmers of the land fled upon sighting the armed group.

On 10 June 2019, an LRA group, comprised of 3 armed men and 16 unarmed boys, looted fields southwest of Obo. The assailants held 14 civilians, including 2 mothers with 3 children, for several hours. The group released 9 of the civilians but abducted the 5 remaining men.

actor1: RJ: Revolution and Justice (Aile Sayo Faction)

actor2: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic

On 2 June 2019, in Paoua, several dozen of women protested against 3R killings in the city.[size=several dozen]
On 29 May 2019, in Bambari, 50 people protested against rotation of MINUSCA troops and arrival of Mauritanian soldiers due to rumors of latter collaborating with ex-Seleka militia. [size=50]

actor1: PRNC: Party of the Rally of the Central African Nation

On 26 May 2019, near Mboki, 2 LRA elements ambushed a young man, his wife, and child. They ordered the man to go buy them flour, while they held his family hostage. They also looted 2 other men. They released all of the victims once the man returned with the flour.

actor1: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: On 26 May 2019, in Paoua, FACA Capitan has shot several times at president of Paoua Youth in what is believed to be unsuccessful assassination attempt. MINUSCA Human Rights Section is monitoring the situation.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: On 26 May 2019, in Bambari, UPC militiamen have been attacking and robbing local community members.

source: aBangui; Centrafrique Presse Info; Africa 1; AFP; BBC News; Le Potentiel; Corbeau News; RFI; VOA; Twitter; Cameroon Tribune; AP; Jeune Afrique
notes: On 21 May 2019, in Koundjili, Djoumjoum and several other villages of Ouham Pende, 3R has attacked and massacred 50 civilians. The group is one of the 14 armed groups that signed the Sudan Peace and Unity Accord with the CAR government on February 5. The killings caused international outcry and statements by MINUSCA and CAR Government's ultimatum to the leader of the group to hand culprits.

actor1: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)

On 18 May 2019, in Bangui, ex-Seleka combatants protested against arrest of one of their members by CAR Police by blocking one of the city roads. The arrest was caused by attempts of illegal installation of commercial kiosk [size=several dozen].
12 May 2019 (on or before). A mob lynched a suspected thief, in a neighborhood next to the PK5 neighborhood of Bangui.
12 May 2019. After the lynching of a thief, an armed group in PK5 neighborhood of Bangui carried out reprisal attacks in the neighborhood, killing at least two people.

09 May 2019. After a dispute between herders and farmers in Bokpangna, 3R combatants killed a farmer and injured four others in Bokpangna, Ouham Pende (coordinates are approximate based on location 57 km from Bozoum along the Bocaranga axis).

notes: 08 May 2019. A group of armed Fulani killed a male youth in Bozoy 2, Paoua (no coordinates available).

07 May 2019. A mob caught a foreigner (nationality unspecified) suspected of robbing and killing a man the night before in Obo. The mob assaulted the man until MINUSCA and FACA intervened. [size=no report]

05 May 2019 (on or around). During the beginning of May, an armed group of Fulani abducted 10 people from Boganagone, Lobaye (no coordinates available). 28 April 2019. The LRA abducted two farmers 3 km from Zemio. The assailants released the abductees the next day.

19 April 2019. A group of armed pastoralists fired at two men who went to pick-up an ox they purchased 5 km from Amou, Kemo, killing one of the men and seriously injuring the other.
19 April 2019. Following an attack on two men by pastoralists, residents of Amau attacked the Fulani community. At least six people were killed and several houses were burned.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: On 9 April 2019, the UPC and Zangba self-defense militia clashed near the Zangba-Alindao road. Later they burned 19 villages. 12 fatalities were reported in total - spread between two events (the clash and attack on civilians).

actor1: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
actor2: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
notes: 08 April 2019. The FACA clashed with FDPC combatants in Foro, Baboua. Three militia members were killed and one commander was captured.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: 04-08 April 2019. Following clashes with a self-defense militia in Zangba, the UPC burned down 19 villages and killed 100 people in the Zangba territory. The fatalities are spread across five days of attacks - including 18 fatalities reported on 4 April in villages including Kesse, Gbari, Yambourou, Yaligo, and Yeou. The attacks prompted a large-scale displacement of the local population.

assoc_actor_2: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: 06 April 2019. An unidentified armed group killed the mayor of the Cocho-Toulou district and his accountant while they were traveling to Goya, Kouango.

actor1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
notes: 04 April 2019 (on or before). The FPRC systematically extorted aid organizations and civilian drivers in Bria, taxing them on all vehicles and drivers licenses.

assoc_actor_2: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
notes: 04 April 2019. An unidentified armed group stopped a local MSF staff member as he was traveling from Batangafo to Bouca. The assailants held the victim captive in the bush before killing him.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: On 4 April 2019, following clashes with a self-defense militia, the UPC attacked 4 villages in Zangba (Basse-Kotto) including Kesse, Gbari, Yambourou, Yaligo, and Yeou. They killed 18 people and injured over forty. The attacks prompted a large-scale displacement of the local population.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: 03 April 2019 (on or around). The UPC clashed with a community defense group in the Zanga sub-prefecture. This triggered four days of attacks by the UPC on villages in the area (coded separately).

notes: 01 April 2019. Prisoners tried to escape breaking their cells' doors in a prison in Bangui. Police forces intervened and restored order. [size=no report]

'One national INGO staff member was injured when armed assailants reportedly began shooting at the group riding motorcycles around 1:10pm. The staff member and 3 others were travelling near the town of Pavika on the Alindao-Bangassou axis, when their group was attacked on the road. The injured staff member was admitted to a local hospital for treatment.'

28 March 2019. An armed group shot and killed a hunter in the Lybi area (no coordinates available, located near Sibut along the Damara road). Locals have accused pastoralists in the area.

assoc_actor_2: Government of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: 27 March 2019. An unidentified group assaulted the Minister of Youth and Sports, Lionel Dounda, outside of his office in Bangui.

26 March 2019. Suspected Anti-Balaka forces raided the Danga village (no coordinates available, located in the Damara district- 65 km from Bangui). The assailants fired shots and went door-to-door abducting four civilians. More than 1,000 local residents fled to the bush and Bangui.

22 March 2019 (on or before). A group of armed Fulani pastoralists killed a farmer in Kella Doukou, Nana Mambere following a dispute over their herds grazing on the victim's land.
22 March 2019 (on or before). Following the attack on Fulani pastoralist in Kella Doukou, 3R forces mobilized around the town. The group blames the Anti-Balaka for the attack on the Fulani.

'One national INGO employee was shot and wounded by two armed assailants while reportedly distributing food near Bamara-Kassai (17km North of Batangafo). The staff member was evacuated to Batangafo for medical attention, and the assailants fled before a UN patrol arrived.'
14 March 2019. Recent graduates protested in Bangui against the inclusion of armed actors in government positions. [size=no report]

11 - 21 March. An unidentified armed group blocks the road between Bangui and Garoua Boulay of Cameroon for 10 days, leaving many drivers stranded. Rebel groups claim the current presidential cabinet is not representative of the population.

actor2: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa

actor2: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: 07 and 9 March 2019. The Boulangba self-defense militia clashed with UPC forces in Boulangba and Kandia in Basse Kotto (unclear if clashes in both villages on both days; coded as two events, one in Boulangba prec1 on 7 March, one in Boulangba prec2 on 9 March as no coordinates available for Kandia). Houses were also burned down. Six combatants - five from the self-defense group and one UPC fighter- were killed during the clashes. The fatalities are spread between the two events.

assoc_actor_1: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic

07 March 2019. The Boulangba self-defense militia robbed a trader who was leaving the Boulangba, Basse Kotto to travel to Mobaye. The event triggered clashes with the UPC (coded separately).

actor2: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)

notes: 20 February. The humanitarian corridor along the Mobaye-Kongbo road in Basse-Kotto was reopened following an agreement between the local government and armed groups (UPC and Anti-Balaka).

05 - 19 February. An unidentified armed group abducted and killed 14 civilians in the area surrounding Obo town during this period. This includes five South Sudanese street traders stabbed to death on the 19th. Coded as three events on each week with the fatalities spread across the three events.
18 February 2019. An unidentified armed group shot at a man and woman on a bike along the Bria-Nzako road, near Manzala. The man was injured.
18 February. Five trader went missing. Their bodies were discovered on 23/02 near Bozongui, Haut Mbomou. The bodies appeared to have been murdered.
13 February. LRA combatants attacked Ligoua, Obo. The perpetrators looted the town and abducted three civilians.
12 February 2019. An LRA group - consisting of five women and five men - attacked Ligoua, Haut-Mbomou. The assailants looted goods and abducted three people, including one child.

05 - 19 February. An unidentified armed group abducted and killed 14 civilians in the area surrounding Obo town during this period. This includes five South Sudanese street traders stabbed to death on the 19th. Coded as three events on each week with the fatalities spread across the three events.

assoc_actor_1: Former Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)
notes: 11 February. Retired soldiers demonstrated in Bangui over the delay of payments owed to them by the government.

08 February. Suspected Sudanese poachers killed three Fulani, including a 9 year old child, 20 km outside of Obo. The assailants also robbed two non-Muslims in the area, who returned to Obo and reported the event to MINUSCA. The family of the Fulani victims suspect the involvement of those who reported the incident. However, there is a long-standing dispute between Fulani and Sudanese poachers which others report as the reasoning for the killing of the Fulani and release of the Christians.

28 January. Thousands of protesters demonstrated in Bangui, calling for the removal of the arms embargo on the country. The embargo expires on 30/01. On 31/01 the UN announced that it extended the embargo until September 2019.

On 28 November 2018, ex-Seleka militia members attempted to rob a weapons cache from Anti-Balaka members in Batangafo town (Batangafo, Ouham) . An Anti-Balaka member was found killed after the incident, likely armed.

On 27 November 2018, in Bangui town (Bangui, Bangui), Bangui militia members shot and killed a trader to avenge the murder of Mahamat Tahir, the leader of a Bangui militia who was killed during an exchange of fire with a shop merchant two days priro.
On 25 November 2018, in Bangui town (Bangui, Bangui), Mahamat Tahir, the leader of a Bangui militia was killed during an exchange of fire with a shop merchant who refused to obey his orders.
24 November. Two aid workers were abducted by an armed group while traveling on the Bria-Irrabanda road. They were released on 03/12.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic

On 21 November 2018, militiamen from Bangui's Miskine Christian neighbourhood carried out a knife attack targeting 2 Muslim youngsters in the PK5 neighbourhood. This sparked wider clashes.

On 21 November 2018, the targeting of 2 Muslim youngsters in the PK5 neighbourhood by Miskime militiamen sparked wider clashes in the area, which involved gunfire and grenades, and resulted in the death of 2 people and the injury of 6.
On 20 November 2018, fire exchange in Bangui's PK5 area was reported. Although the source left the actors unidentified, it suggested that PK5 militiamen were likely to be involved.

On 20 November 2018, Muslim PK5 militiamen held a small protest in Bangui's PK5 area holding signs against Russian presence in the country. This took place after an attack on the HQs of PK5 leader 'Force' on Nov 17, which some attributed to a Russian drone.

On 17 November 2018, at 0200 GMT, unidentified gunmen attacked the HQs of Nimery Matar ('Force'), leader of the communal/vigilante PK5 militia, in the 3rd district of Bangui. Casualties were reported - unclear if fatalities or injuries.
On 17 November 2018, clashes were reported between unidentified groups in the Ouham region.

01 - 30 November. During the month of November, 3R forces moved into Siriri territory in Nana Mambere, where they forcibly recruited Siriri members into 3R.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: On 15 November 2018, Anti-Balaka fighters attacked Muslim civilians in the town of Alindao, prompting a reaction from UPC fighters. The UPC, along with members of a local militia calling themselves the Mujahedin, attacked an IDP camp hosting around 20,000 Christians which the Anti-Balaka operated out of. The UPC also brought civilians into the camps during the attacks, but it is unclear if they were used as shields to prevent a reaction from MINUSCA or if the civilians participated in the attack. The Anti-Balaka clashed with the UPC in the camp but ran out of ammunition, at which point UPC forces overran the site. At least 112 people were killed in these incidents (MINUSCA obtained in-depth information on at least 69 victims, while the rest of the names were given by local humanitarian organisations) , with no more precision about the nature of the dead (civilian or combatant) apart from two priests - fatalities split across three distinct events.

notes: 31 October. Following two separate attacks on Muslims and Fulani the same morning (coded separately), the MPC, FPRC and armed Muslims attacked IDP camps, homes, the church and the market in Batangafo. IDP camps were targeted as the attackers suspected Anti-Balaka of hiding in them. Eleven people were killed and 37 were injured. Investigations that the attackers sought to permanently remove IDPs from the town by destroying the camps but the perpetrators instructed women and children IDPs to flee their huts before they were set on fire, elderly and disabled persons accounted for the majority of fatalities according to MSF.

The following day, the CNDS (a coalition of ex-Seleka groups) urged all groups associated with the government to vacate the areas under their control within 48 hours, although a separate statement issued by FPRC denied this ultimatum.

The victims are believed to have been attacked on three distinct occasions by unknown armed men amidst rising insecurity in Obo. Coded as three separate events, each with one fatality.
12 September. Three herders were killed in the Kouango sub-prefecture. Locals along the Kouango-Pende axis have fled the area in fear of a reprisal attack. No further details.
Non-violent activity: 11 September. Approximately 45 armed men, believed to be from 3R forces have reportedly entered the village of Mboko Tatale. The reason for their presence remains unknown.
11 September. Armed men broke into an NGO office in Batangafo, took three security guards and two staff members hostge and stole equipment and money before leaving.

notes: Clashes between Anti-Balaka and suspected UPC fighters in the Bakouma area were reported to have moved into the city. A military source said 20 people, mainly civilians, had been killed during the clashes (10 coded in previous event).

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: At least 50 people were killed and dozens more injured, allegedly by UPC fighters, in the Agoudou-Manga area, including in Yassenemem, Agoudou-Manga and Nyouyanza villages. UPC denies their involvement.

actor1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
notes: UPC sources say FPRC fighters have been raided villages in the Agoudou-Manga area controlled by the UPC. No casualties were reported.
A person kidnapped from Bangari village was killed during an attack the next day on Bodiba village in the same area. Livestock was stolen in both villages.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: On 20 March 2017, anti-balaka and FPRC fighters in the towns of Wadja Wadja and Agoudou-Manga, suspecting an upcoming UPC attack, ordered town residents to move to Yassine for their safety. However, at about 5 a.m. the next day, UPC fighters attacked Yassine, killing at least 18 civilians, including at least 10 children.
One person was killed and 4 kidnapped in an attack by unidentified assailants on Bagari village on the Nguia-Bouar road. Livestock was also reported stolen.

actor2: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: At least 10 people were killed during a clash between Anti-Balaka and former Seleka militiamen of the UPC in villages around Bakouma.
25 people were reportedly kidnapped by LRA fighters in the Djema sub-prefecture.

Anti-balaka fighters attacked three Peuhl men in Yassine, a town in a gold- producing area northeast of Bambari, which had been under UPC control since 2014. Two of the men died - three witnesses described both men as local butchers who had not participated in fighting. A third man said he narrowly escaped after a bullet grazed his shoulder.

7 suspected LRA forces looted the community of Louete, CAR. They stole food and abducted a 15-year-old girl. They spoke Acholi and Sango and were armed with rifles and AK-type weapons. [women targeted: girls]

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: The FPRC has accused the UPC of killing as many as 80 people in the Agoudou-Manga area.

Students from the Faculty of Economics and Management at the University of Bangui protested and blocked the entrance to the school's administration to demand an extension to the registration period after as many as 1,500 students were unable to register before the deadline. The PM intervened to defuse the situation and reassure the students.

actor1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
notes: The UPC has accused the FPRC of burning villages in the Agoudou-Manga area and killing as many as 45 civilians. The FPRC disputes these claims.
2 traders were killed and 7 people kidnapped by LRA fighters in a raid on Koumbadoule village, 16km from Zemio.
A clash was reported between Anti-Balaka and former Seleka fighters in the Bamou neighbourhood of Kaga-Bandoro. No casualty figures were reported.
5 people were abducted by LRA fighters, including a village chief, during a raid on Kpiyamou village, 40km from Rafai. They also looted and ransacked the village. The chief was later released.

At least 11 people were killed by an unidentified armed group in the Danga-Gboudou locality in the villages of Mambissi (9) and Tagbara (2) between roughly Mar.8-12. Several other people were wounded and headed to Bambari for treatment.

Looting: 6 suspected LRA forces ambushed and looted 6 travelers on their way to Zemio, CAR. The victims were looted of clothes, mobile phones, an MP3 player, and money. The assailants wore a mix of civilian and military clothing, and spoke Acholi, Swahili, and Lingala.
3 hunters were kidnapped by LRA fighters near Zemio. One of the hunters later escaped.

actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: A Senegalese peacekeeper was injured by unidentified assailants in Bangui, and later died of his wounds in hospital.

actor1: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: Looting: Vehicles being escorted between Grimai and Bambari were stopped and looted by Anti-Balaka fighters. It was not clear if the two groups fought during the incident.

A suspected LRA group attacked pastoralists northwest of Rafai, CAR. The group of assailants was comprised of men, women and children. They killed 2 cows and reportedly held the pastoralists captive for a few hours.

actor1: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
actor2: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
notes: One FPRC fighter was killed and at least 7 others wounded in a helicopter gunship attack by MINUSCA on a column of 40 FPRC fighters advancing on Bambari.

5 LRA forces abducted 11 civilians in Gambara, CAR. The assailants wore a mix of civilian and military clothing, boots, and they spoke Acholi and Zande. They looted the community of cassava, peanuts, rice, clothes, shoes, and handheld FM radios.

A large group of suspected LRA forces ambushed and abducted at least 7 civilians south of Ngouyo, CAR. The assailants looted salt, bags of clothes, money, an MP3 player, phones, and shoes from the victims whom they forced to porter the looted goods.
A commercial vehicle was attacked by suspected former Seleka militiamen, killing one and injuring several others in Yagarandji village in the Kaga-Bandoro area.

Looting: 4 suspected LRA forces speaking Acholi and armed with AK-type weapons looted 3 cyclists south of Ngouyo, CAR. The victims reported that the assailants told them they were separated into two groups, one in the north and on in the south.

3 suspected LRA forces ambushed a cyclist near Ngouyo, CAR. The assailants spoke Acholi, Sango, and Zande. They wore military clothing and were armed with AK-type weapons. The assailants looted him of clothes, shoes, and 22,000 CFA, and held him captive overnight.
People in Bangui's 2nd arrondissement protested to demand the collection of garbage in their area which has fallen behind. They blocked traffic for a few hours.
Looting: Suspected 4 LRA forces speaking Acholi, Zande, and Sango, looted a cyclist south of Ngouyo, CAR. The victim reportedly ran away, abandoning his bicycle.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: The leader of the UPC, Ali Darass, and some Anti-Balaka leaders left Bambari after a request by MINUSCA and protests by its inhabitants. This is in the context of threats by the FPRC-MPC that they would attack the city to get at the UPC. Many UPC fighters remained in the city.

Residents of Bambari protested to demand the departure of Ali Darass, the leader of the UPC, from the city. Two marches occurred, one from the IDP camp protected by Sangaris and another from the Kidijigra neighbourhood of the city.

actor1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: 4 MINUSCA peacekeepers were injured, one seriously, in a clash with FPRC fghters near Ippy.

actor1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: MINUSCA peacekeepers clashed with FPRC fighters near Ippy, killing one and wounding another.
A suspected thief was killed by unidentified assailants in the Bozoum area following a robbery.

Suspected LRA forces attacked Derbissaka, CAR, and looted a number of households of food and non-food items. The assailants reportedly fired warning shots with AK-type weapons and abducted 4 community members as porters, including 2 women.
In mid-February anti-balaka fighters ambushed a group of civilians on a truck in the village of Ndoussoumba (central regions), killing at least 16 Peuhl civilians.

actor2: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
notes: Armed men from Chad wearing military uniforms entered Kaga-Bandoro and began shooting in the air, causing many residents to flee the area. They announced their intention to join the FPRC in their offensive against the UPC in Bambari.
LRA fighters attacked Karmada village, near Derbissaka. No details reported.
At least one person was killed in an attack on Bera village by armed Fulani. Houses were also set on fire.

actor1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
notes: The FPRC says it has taken control of Ippy ahead of their advance on Bambari to dislodge UPC fighters.

actor1: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
actor2: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
notes: The chief of staff of the FPRC and another fighter were killed in a MINUSCA airstrike on FPRC fighters as they advanced on Bambari. An FPRC spokesman said 3 civilians were killed and 5 others wounded, as well as houses destroyed during the airstrike. The attack took place just a few kms outside of Ippy at Ngawa 1. MINUSCA has declared attacking Bambari a 'red line' that should not be crossed.

actor1: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
notes: Following an attack on the village of Bera by armed Fulani, members of the FDPC pursued and caught up with those responsible, recovering some of the property they stole. No casualties were reported.
3 people were killed and as many as 365 homes looted/burned as suspected former Seleka militiamen attacked Bowai village in the Nana-Bakassa area.
2 women were abducted and homes/businesses were burned in Derbissaka village (Rafia) by LRA rebels.

Members of Youssouf Sy's militia from PK5 stormed a local UN-run health centre where some people injured in recent reprisals following the death of their group's leader were staying. No casualties were reported however.
Several hundred people protested on the tarmac at Mpoko airport to demand the disarmament of armed groups in the PK5 neighbourhood of Bangui.

actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-) Gendarmerie
notes: The leader of a PK5 militia, Youssouf Sy (aka Big Man), one of his fighters and 2 civilians were killed during a joint operation by MINUSCA and CAR gendarmerie in the PK5 neighbourhood of Bangui. 3 gendarmerie personnel were also injured in the raid.

assoc_actor_2: Journalists (Central African Republic); Christian Group (Central African Republic)
source: AFP; RFI; RCA (Central African Republic); AP
notes: A journalist and a pastor were killed and at least 24 people wounded in neighbourhoods around PK5 during reprisals after Youssouf Sy (aka Big Man), the head of a PK5 militia, was killed by a joint MINUSCA-CAR gendarmerie operation. At least 2 churches were also set on fire by the fighters.
A suspected LRA group abducted 13 civilians in Ngoulia, CAR, to porter looted goods from the community.
Looting: Suspected LRA forces attacked the mining camp of Yangou Bayoka, CAR (near Mbangana), twice on the same day. They looted sugar, rice, and cassava flour. All the miners fled in the bush.

actor1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
assoc_actor_1: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
actor2: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: FRPC-MPC and UPC fighters have engaged in clashes in the Ndassima between Feb.4-7, resulting in at least 20 people killed (fatalities coded across 4 events). The UPC fighters allegedly withdrew from the areas to Bamodo, but later took the cities back.

actor1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa

notes: FRPC-MPC and UPC fighters have engaged in clashes in the Ndassima between Feb.4-7, resulting in at least 20 people killed (fatalities coded across 4 events). The UPC fighters allegedly withdrew from the areas to Bamodo, but later took the cities back.

15 people were killed in clashes in and around Bocaranga between 3R and Anti-Balaka fighters. Some casualties were reported among the town's civilians, and many people were displaced. MINUSCA forces intervened in a clash between Anti-Balaka and 3R fighters in Bocaranga, opening fire on both sides to end the fighting.

assoc_actor_1: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
actor2: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
source: RFI; Agence Congolaise de Presse; RCA (Central African Republic)
notes: FRPC-MPC and UPC fighters clashed in the Djoubissi areas of Ouaka. The UPC allegedly withdrew from the area but later retook it. No fatalities were reported.

RRR fighters attacked Bocaranga in the early morning on Feb.3, firing into the air to scare the population before looting several shops and vandalizing a church. At least 50 people took refuge at the local MONUSCA camp. At least 10 people were reported killed in the attack. Both the Danish Refugee Council and IRC were allegedly looted during the attack.

actor1: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: Deployment:MINUSCA forces have been drawn in from smaller bases and redeployed around Bambari after recent fighting between different ex-Seleka factions and fears of an impending attack on the town.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: Clashes were reported between UPC and Anti-Balaka fighters in Ngaboko. At least one Anti-Balaka leader was killed and another seriously injured, while at least 2 civilians were reportedly left in comas after the fighting.
Suspected LRA forces held 3 women captive overnight near the community of Bahr, CAR.

Looting: Suspected LRA forces attacked a cyclist on his way to Mboki from Obo, CAR. The assailants wore a mix of civilian and military clothing, they had AK-type weapons, and spoke Acholi and Sango. They looted all of his belongings as well as a bag of sugar.

A large number of former Seleka fighters from several groups have been gathering in Bambari recently, causing concern among the population and administration of the city. The UN also warned the former Seleka groups against any conflict around the city which is a major aid distribution point.

A large group of suspected LRA forces attacked a motorcyclist on his way to Zemio, CAR, from Banangui, CAR. The group of assailants was comprised of men, women, and children. They asked the man for food and temporarily held him captive.
A group of young Anti-Balaka members attempted to set fire to the house of a man and lynch him for allegedly causing the death of a deputy in Damara using 'sorcery'. The man escaped unharmed.

Suspected LRA forces attacked the mining camp of Gbodio, 7 km south of Malacha in Haute-Kotto, CAR. The assailants were armed with AK-type weapons, and wore a mix of civilian and military clothing. They looted food and non-food items from the mining camp. Coordinates are approximate based on location 7km south of Malacha.

Suspected LRA forces attacked a pastoralist camp near Zemio, CAR. The group of assailants was comprised of men, women and children. Some of the men were armed, and wore a mix of civilian and military clothing. They killed a number of cows.

Looting: LRA forces attacked 3 traders 10 km from Mboki, CAR. The assailants wore a mix of civilian and military clothing, and were armed with AK-type weapons. They spoke Sango, Acholi, and Zande. A trader was looted of cassava and meat.

6 suspected LRA forces including 2 men and 4 boys of less than 18, attacked a camp in a field north of Mboki, CAR. They looted peanuts, cassava, a motorbike battery, and palm wine. They abducted 3 people and forced them to porter the looted goods.
Young people who accused a woman of witchcraft in the Bougoumara area near Batangafo buried her alive. [women targeted: accused of witchcraft/sorcery]
Anti-Balaka fighters ambushed a vehicle near Bozoum and robbed its passengers.
Taxi and bus drivers engaged in a work stoppage over harassment by the police.
LRA fighters abducted 3 civilians northwest of Mboki. One of the hostages was given money to buy supplies in return for the release of the other two.

Suspected Anti-Balaka fighters shot some civilians in Bozoum after the local MINUSCA contingent withdrew from the city over allegations of trading in liquor. The base was looted soon after the contingent left by suspected Anti-Balaka fighters as well.
2 Ugandan soldiers were killed by suspected LRA fighters who ambushed them in Kitife village in the Zemio area. Several civilians were also wounded during the ambush.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: A man and his two children were killed by UPC fighters in Mourouba, near Bakala.

Suspected LRA forces attacked a pastoralist camp near Yangou Brindi, CAR, killing 3 cows and taking the meat. The group was comprised of men, women, and children. The men were armed with AK-type weapons and wore a mix of civilian and military clothing.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: In January, Human Rights Watch documented other killings of civilians by the UPC, including 2 civilians killed in Kpele.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: In January, Human Rights Watch documented several killings of civilians by the UPC in the Bambari area, including an unknown number in Ouropo and at least four in Moko.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: In January, Human Rights Watch documented several killings of civilians by the UPC in the Bambari area, including an unknown number in Ouropo and at least four in Moko. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.

Looting: Suspected LRA forces attacked Gambatoure, CAR. They were armed with AK type weapons, and dressed in military and civilian clothing. The group consisted of men, women and children.They looted food and communications equipment from the community.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: UPC fighters have allegedly set up a base in Ngolo village, located a few kilometers from Bakouma

A woman was attacked by a group of youth in Berberati after being accused of being a witch and involved in the death of a young man in a hunting accident. MINUSCA forces intervened and saved the woman. [women targeted: accused of witchcraft/sorcery]

actor1: MPC: Patriotic Movement for Central African Republic
notes: Women whose husbands are part of the former Seleka coalition have been attacked recently by MPC members in Kaga Bandoro. The MPC are allegedly looking for information on their relatives who are fighters. [women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

Clashes were reported in the Ouham-Pende localities of Pende and Santouwane between RRR and Anti-Balaka fighters. As many as 6 RRR fighters were killed in these clashes, and 2 Anti-Balaka fighters seriously injured. The fatalities were disaggregated between the two locations. The coordinates for Santouwane are approximate, based on information provided in an ACF report.

Clashes were reported in the Ouham-Pende localities of Pende and Santouwane between RRR and Anti-Balaka fighters. As many as 6 RRR fighters were killed in these clashes, and 2 Anti-Balaka fighters seriously injured. The fatalities were disaggregated between the two locations.

actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: MINUSCA fighters were attacked in the Bocaranga area by Anti-Balaka fighters, resulting in at least one Bangladeshi peacekeeper killed. RRR forces were also reported in the area, but it was not clear if they participated in the event.

actor1: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
source: AFP; Maghreb Emergent; RCA (Central African Republic)
notes: 2 Moroccan peacekeepers were killed in an attack by unidentified gunmen on a MINUSCA convoy traveling in the Mboki area. 2 soldiers were also injured.
Residents of Ngaoundaye protested and barricaded the main road to Bangui over the withdrawal of Cameroonian peacekeepers from their area.

assoc_actor_2: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
notes: A second attack on MSF workers was reported in Bambari, although no injuries were reported.

actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic
notes: At least 10 civilians were reported killed in a UPC attack on Yambele, southeast of Bambari, by HRW.

actor1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
notes: A large number of FPRC fighters from Ndele, Bamingui and other localities have gathered in Mbres following recent clashes in Bria. This has caused issue with the local population and 'paralyzed activities' in the city.

A clash between two youths, which resulted in one dead, led to a larger gunfight in Batangafo. Few details were reported but it seems the fight may have happened in a stronghold of ex-combatants of the Seleka coalition. The source said it did not hold any reliable information to confirm whether the ex-Seleka had fired shots.

assoc_actor_2: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
notes: An MSF staff member was wounded in a robbery by unidentified assailants in the Bambari area.
A hunter was kidnapped by a group of armed men in Djiba village, near Baboua.
National Urban Transport Company (SONATU) staff and Central African Telecommunications Corporation (SOCATEL) staff staged demos in different parts of Bangui over backpay.
Unidentified assailants attacked Bondiba near Baboua, killing one person and wounding several others. The assailants were allegedly searching for oxen stolen by FPRC fighters.
LRA rebels raided another town near Nzako.
LRA rebels kidnapped 17 people, including a religious leader, in Kono village near Nzako.
A breeder was kidnapped by LRA fighters just outside Obo.

MINUSCA forces intervened to end the clashes in the various districts. actor1: UPC: Union for Peace in the Central African Republic

The fighting occurred in part due to the militiamen restricting cattle movement. MIINUSCA forces later intervened and stopped the clashes in Batangafo.

actor2: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2016-)

source: AFP; RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka

Elements of the gendarmerie sent to the area over the previous weekend left the area for Bozoum following the attack, although no specific interactions were reported between the security forces and the assailants.
Looting: A Capuchin mission was attacked by former Seleka rebels in the Ngaoundaye area. They looted the mission for food. No injuries were reported.

Traders from Bimbo market organized a march to oppose their relocation to a new site.

Negotiations had been ongoing with the Fulani to enter the city with their flocks but without their weapons, but they refused to disarm, which resulted in the clash after 3 armed Fulani youths were arrested in the morning. The commander of the brigade which opposed them and other members of the security forces were wounded in the gunfight.
A confrontation occurred between the residents of Zemio and Ugandan forces in the area after a quarrel between a Ugandan soldier and a resident over a woman.

A 73 year old man was murdered along the river to the village Ouaka Gala Bouruma by a group of ex-Seleka.
Suspected PK5 militiamen supported by MINUSCA forces killed two people in Ngou ciment neighborhood of Bangui. Residents marched in front of the Radio Ndeke Luka office the flollowing day in protest.
'A national INGO staff member in Kaga-Bandoro was shot and killed when armed robbers broke into his house. Another INGO staff member from a different INGO was also killed by a gunshot wound.'

Clashes between PK5 militia and unidentified gunmen at Sarah in Banguis 3rd neighborhood over livestock, leaving one killed.
Fighting was heard during the night in Bambari.

actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: During clashes between anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka forces near a MINUSCA outpost, at least one Cameroonian peacekeeper was killed. It was not clear who killed the peackeeper.
Anti-Balaka and former Seleka forces clashed in Batangafo.

After 2 members of an ex-Seleka group were killed, the armed group attacked an IDP camp, burning over 700 shelters and spreading fear and violence throughout the camp, causing 10,000 people to flee to Batangafo hospital. At least 3 civilians were killed and 30 injured.
Unidentified assailants killed 2 young Muslims who were members of an ex-Seleka militia outside of an IDP camp near Batangafo.
At least 1 person was shot dead and several houses and stalls were burned during clashes between Muslims and Anti-Balaka forces in Bangui, particularly in PK4 and Bea-Rex neighbourhoods.

assoc_actor_1: COMIC: Coordination of the Central Muslim Community
notes: Members of the Coordination of the Central Muslim Community organized a rally ensure freedom of movement for Muslims and rearmament of the FACA.
1 person was killed and several others injured after anti-Balaka attacked a vehicle owned by former Seleka rebels near Liwa.
Clashes between anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka fighters resulted in 3 fatalities in Bambari.

Some students protested at the University of Bangui against the dissolution of the executive of the National Association of Central African Students (ANECA) and set up barricades which disrupted activities.
Over 900 people fled a UNHCR camp near Awatche village after an attack on the area by an unidentified armed group.

assoc_actor_2: WFP: World Food Programme; Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
notes: 2 people were killed, including an employee of the WFP, when armed men threw grenades at a barrier in PK12, in the north part of Bangui.

One hundred parliamentarians of the National Transitional Council participated in a peaceful march to denounce the recent violence in Bangui and demand the rapid rearmament of the Central African Armed Forces (FACA).

actor1: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Central Office for the Repression of Banditry
notes: A man accused of leading a lynching of a witch, who was also the leader of an anti-Balaka group in Lobaye province, was summarily executed by the OCRB in Bangui.

actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)

actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)

Two unidentified assailants threw grenades in the University of Bangui, injuring students.

A woman believed to be a witch who was accused of killing a young girl was beaten to death by a group of villagers led by the leader of an anti-Balaka group (the group who killed the witch was not reported as anti-Balaka fighters). [women targeted: accused of witchcraft/sorcery]

At least 3 people were killed, 22 injured, and over a hundred houses burned during clashes between anti-Balaka forces and Muslim militias from PK5 in Bangui. International forces were allegedly entirely absent during the violence.

2 people were killed and several wounded during sectarian violence between Muslim and Christian militias following the deaths of some Muslim motorcycle taxi drivers a few days before which has led to ongoing violence.

assoc_actor_2: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016); Women (Central African Republic)

At least 4 people were killed, 20 wounded, and several houses burned, including those of the heads of the Kina and Kokoro neighbourhoods during reprisals by armed Muslims from the KM5 against the 3rd and 6th districts of Bangui following the killing of 2 young Muslim motorcycle taxi drivers in the 6th district.

At least 2 young motorcycle taxi drivers believed to be Muslims were killed by unidentified men in the 6th district of Bangui. It is not clear why they were killed, but the murder of Muslim taxi drivers has recently led to significant violence in CARs largest cities.

At least 4 people were killed, 20 wounded, and several houses burned, including those of the heads of the Kina and Kokoro neighbourhoods during reprisals by armed Muslims from the KM5 against the 3rd and 6th districts of Bangui following the killing of 2 young Muslim motorcycle taxi drivers in the 6th district.
Self-defense groups who do not identify as anti-Balaka or Seleka have started forming in Bangui in response to the resurgence of violence in the capital.
2 young Muslims were found dead (believed to have been killed the night of Oct.28) in a mostly Christian neighbourhood of Bangui on the morning of Oct.29.

Residents of Lakouanga in the PK5 neighbourhood protested against renewed violence in the area.

notes: Anti-Balaka members attacked a delegation of 4 former Seleka rebels from the UPC in the 8th district of Bangui after they arrived in the city at the invitation of the government for talks. 1 member of the delegation was seriously injured, at least 2 were killed, and the situation for the last is unknown.
3 Christians were killed in alleged retaliatory violence after UPC representatives were attacked by anti-Balaka members.
3 people were kidnapped by suspected LRA rebels near Ligoua. They were found dead on Oct.31 in the same area.

Anti-Balaka militias based in Bogangolo attacked and killed six villagers and burned houses in the Maraze area, close to Bouca.
Some villagers hunted down and killed the alleged perpatrator of a crime. The man killed was an anti-Balaka member, leading to later reprisals (coded in a separate event).

assoc_actor_2: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)

Looting: Unidentified gunmen looted the offices of an NGO ('Appui au developpement') in Banguis 5th arrondissement. Several other cases of robbery were reported during the day in the capital.

source: Radio Ndeke Luka; AFP; Centrafrique Presse Info; RCA (Central African Republic)
notes: Three people killed and 10 wounded, primarily civilians, after anti-Balaka forces attacked the neighbourhood of PK5 in Bangui. They were opposed by self-defense committees from the district. Heavy gunfire was heard for about an hour, until MINUSCA intervened to disperse the two groups.
6 people have been killed in the Obo area around the end of October (3 fatalities coded in another event).

3 people were killed and 7 injured after clashes between two groups of anti-Balaka related to a conflict over the chain of command. The 'author of the disorders and other anti-Balaka' were among those killed. Calm returned after the intervention of MINUSCA forces.

actor1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
notes: Former Seleka rebels from the FPRC faction raided the town of Kouango, shooting in all directions and setting buildings on fire. At least 2 people were wounded during the incident.

notes: Unidentified assailants kidnapped 4 MSF staff members from their office in Bangassou. They were released half an hour later, with one international employee suffering serious injuries.

Anti-Balaka attacked and burned houses in Lema village on the border with the DRC between Oct.12-13, leading to a new surge in refugees crossing into North and South Ubangi. They pursued the refugees and stole their property as well.

Exchanges of fire were heard, including fighting near the National Assembly. Two Total stations at Boy-Rab, in an anti-Balaka stronghold, were also looted and vandalized.

notes: A protest was organized by the Patriotic Movement for the Appropriation of the Destiny of the Country which is calling for the withdrawal of international forces.

The National Transitional Council say that 77 people were killed and 300 injured during violence around Bangui around the end of September following the death of a Muslim motorcycle taxi driver (57 fatalities were coded in other events) based on body counts at morgues around the city. The fatalities include both those engaged in violence and civilians caught in the crossfire.

Protesters in Bangui continued to maintain barricades on the streets following overnight violence in the capital.
2 people were killed in continued clashes in Bangui. The report did not identify which groups were fighting. The violence was particularly notable around the airport.

MINSUCA forces allegedly fired upon the several hundred marchers who were heading to the Office of the President to demand the resignation of the President with live bullets, killing 3 and injuring several, but UN sources dispute this. Most sources agree that three were killed.
Fighting continues between ex-Seleka and anti-Balaka forces in Bangui.

actor2: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
notes: Anti-Balaka gunmen attacked the offices of the national radio station and offices of the national gendarmerie, but they were repelled by the security forces. 5 of the attackers were killed, including an infamous member of the anti-Balaka group, named Mazimbele.

actor2: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Prison Guards
notes: At least 53 prisoners escaped during an attack on a prison in Bouar by about 30 unidentified gunmen. They captured 2 policemen and stole their weapons and looted computers. It was not clear whether they were later released.
Several people were injured when unidentified gunmen threw a grenade in the central market of Kaga-Bandoro. Some shops were also burned.

Looting: The offices of various humanitarian organizations, including IOM, Mercy Corps, Cordaid, Premiere Urgence, the French Red Cross and War Child were looted by anti-Balaka militiamen and local residents during violence in Bangui between Sept.27-28 (unconfirmed reports also said WFP offices were targeted).

Anti-Balaka militiamen retaliated against attacks on a Christian neighbourhood by Muslims (including ex-Seleka) from PK5. Gunfire was heard between the two neighbourhoods. 36 people were said to have died in all between Sept.26-27 (24 were coded in previous events).

A civil society movement dedicated to re-establishing the Central African Armed Forces and restoring peace to CAR organized a demonstration at the Monument of the Martyrs which continued overnight and included a meeting the next day.

actor1: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
notes: The government of CAR has put in place a curfew in Bangui due to the recent violence which has hit the city.

Residents of the 3rd and 5th districts of Bangui erected barricades following violence in their areas. The protesters were also said to be displaying hostility towards international forces and humanitarian workers, along with journalists.

source: AFP; RCA (Central African Republic); RFI; Centrafrique Presse Info
notes: At least 24 people were killed and over 100 injured during riots following the killing of a Muslim motorcycle taxi driver. The initial violence saw Muslims (including ex-Seleka members) attacking a Christian neighbourhood (which included Anti-Balaka members) in retaliation for the killing, until international forces (French/UN) intervened to end the violence. Shops and houses were also allegedly burned, and St. Michaels Parish was looted.
A Muslim motorcycle taxi driver was killed by alleged anti-Balaka attackers in the PK5 district of Bangui, sparking renewed violence in the city.
The Youth Association Gobongo (AJG) organized a peace march in the 8th district of Bangui to condemn violence and the erection of barricades in Gobongo market.

actor2: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
notes: One person was killed and another wounded in a clash between anti-Balaka elements and local police in the Kounde area. The fight appeared to grow out of a threat an anti-Balaka member made to a policemans wife.

actor2: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Gendarmerie
source: Radio Ndeke Luka; RCA (Central African Republic)
notes: Anti-Balaka protesters took to the streets and erected roadblocks to stop traffic in the 4th district of Bangui. It was not clear why they were protesting, but some sources say it had to do with the resignation of the transitional head of state. They also raided the local gendarmie headquarters and released around 15 people being held there.

An unidentified armed group attacked the village of Kpabou near Mboki, killing 3 people and attacking and robbing a motorcycle driver. According to the man who was robbed, the armed men also wore turbans and spoke in Arabic.
Residents of Banguis 6th district engaged in a peaceful march to protest against a grenade attack which occurred on Sept.9.
A group of unidentified armed men took about 50 villagers in Gbodoro, located 12km away from Bakouma, hostage and stole their food and money before leaving their village.

actor1: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: Rwandan MINUSCA forces were ambushed in the 4th district of Bangui by unidentified assailants armed with heavy weapons which caused 'extensive damage' to their armoured vehicles. No casualties were reported.
A group of unidentified armed men invaded invaded a village near Gbodoro, 12km from Bakouma, and stole property and money from the villagers. They also beat them before leaving.

At least 2 people were killed and 22 injured in grenade attacks by unidentified allegedly Muslim youths in Banguis 6th district. The attacks involved at least 2 grenades, at least one of which was thrown at the Air Force One bar, and another near a church in the Fatima area.
Following grenade attacks in Banguis 6th district by allegedly Muslim youths on motorcycles, youths in the area erected roadblocks to block the movement of traffic and protest against the attacks.
Residents of Banguis 2nd district protested against power outages which have allegedly been ongoing for 3 weeks.

notes: 'An agent of the Town Hall was found dead' in the Boukako area of Bambari. It is not clear under what circumstances the municipal worker was killed.

actor1: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: MINUSCA has declared Bambari a weapons-free zone after rival militias clashed in the area.
At least 1,800 new refugees were displaced to the DR-Congo following clashes in the Mobayi-Banga area of CAR between anti-Balaka and Seleka forces.
Ex-Seleka militiamen and anti-Balaka forces clashed in Bambari, after anti-Balaka allegedly attempted to steal a motorcycle from a young Muslim. No casualties were reported.
Looting: 4 suspected anti-Balaka members attacked and looted a vehicle of the NGO JUPEDEC, causing no injuries.

An unidentified armed group accused of creating insecurity in the Bakouma area opened fire on passers-by at the Ndeguilo-Bakouma-Bangassou axis. No specific casualties were reported.

Some anti-Balaka youth allegedly robbed a shop and killed the owner when he attempted to pursue them.
2 people were killed and another died of his injuries in hospital after an attack by suspected armed Fulani herders on Bougourou village.
Ex-Seleka militiamen clashed wth anti-Balaka in Bambari, causing deaths and forcing people to flee the town (fatalities coded as 10).
A woman accused of witchcraft was killed by youths in Yamondo village, located 20km from Sibut. [women targeted: accused of witchcraft/sorcery]

assoc_actor_1: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)

Gunshots and explosions were heard in Bambari as part of ongoing intercommunal clashes.
In continued clashes in Bambari, an additional 10 people were killed over the weekend.
In continued clashes in Bambari, an additional 10 people were killed over the weekend.

A total of ten people were killed and five injured in religious clashes between Anti-balaka and Seleka rebels plus non-Seleka Muslims after a young Muslim was killed by Christians the day before. Volunteers from the Red Cross, both local and international, were also attacked and injured with knives during the clashes.

assoc_actor_2: ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross and Red Crescent; Christian Group (Central African Republic); Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
notes: Red Cross officials and CAR citizens are attacked by Muslim youth while trying to attend to the injured during communal violence between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka fighters. Later in the day, despite the initiation of a dialogue between MINUSCA and the two groups, a Muslim militia killed three Christians in Bornou neighborhood, prolonging clashes the next day.

Bertan Bea, the former Secretary General to ex-President Francois Bea who was arrested on the 15th, was liberated by militants who attacked the court in Bangui. Military and MINUSCA forces around the court reportedly did not fight back.
Anti-balaka reportedly killed a young Muslim man.

actor1: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
notes: Arrests: The secretary-general of the Kwa Na Kwa party of Francois Bozize was arrested as he was about to board a plane for Paris, allegedly related to charges of 'inciting disorder'.

AFP has reported that a 'cattle war' is ongoing in CAR, with violence including the killing and looting of livestock, kidnapping of breeders, and killings and rapes occurring in the western regions, primarily targeted members of the Mbororo ethnic group (fatalities coded as 10).
Election officials in the Bimbo area protested outside the National Authority of Elections headquarters to demand payment of their registration fees.

notes: At least 18 prisoners escaped from a central prison in Ngaragba after taking weapons from the guards. Most of the criminals are suspected to be former members of armed groups. The prison was also protected by international forces.
The village of Badibiri in Obo was raided by LRA fighters. The townspeople fired warning shots into the air to scare the rebels away, but a youth was shot by the rebels during the incident.

actor1: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)

LRA members kidnapped one man while he was on his way from the 'kpo-kpo site' while he was on his way to Bria.
4 people were taken hostage by LRA gunmen from Kpokpo village in the Yalinga area.
About 60 people were taken hostage by suspected LRA members from the village of Mbari, although 45 later escaped.

As many as 357 child soldiers were released by a combination of Christian and Muslim armed groups at 3 ceremonies in the town of Bambari.

1 person was killed when unidentified gunmen opened fire on residents of a mine site outside the town of Nzacko. They then went on to another site and assaulted more people, before stealing food and property.

Several hundreds people, some in military uniforms, erected barricades to protest against the decisions of the Bangui Forum. The protesters blocked traffic with burning tires but were dispersed peacefully by police. They were allegedly largely composed of anti-Balaka members but anti-Balaka leadership said they did not condone the protests.

Angry students who believed their teachers were stealing school supplies rioted and injured at least one teacher.

Students protested at the University of Bangui to demand the payment of scholarships. They erected barrcades and threw projectiles. Traffic was disrupted for several hours on the Avenue des Martyrs and Kongowara Avenue. French forces dispersed the protesters using tear gas.
The National Organization of Disabled People Associations of Central African (ONAPHA) protested over the death of a visually impaired person in Batangafo recently.

2 men were attacked by unidentified armed men believed to be attempted kidnappers. They both escaped but one of the men was wounded and later died at a health centre.

The killing of a young Muslim sparked violent protests in PK5, a predominantly Muslim area, including the closing of all shops. Demonstrators kidnapped 3 leaders of the Muslim community, who tried to calm them down before later releasing them. Anti-Balaka militia fighters fired their weapons and temporarily blocked traffic.

The population of Moussa, CAR, moved to Agoumar, CAR, as a result of the increasing insecurity. The next morning, some of the civilians went back to gather food and sighted 2 granaries in flames and noticed that cassava and potatoes had been stolen.

During the night of Feb.14-15 and the next morning gunfire and grenades were heard going off in PK5, a predominantly Muslim neighbourhood, following the killing of a young Muslim the day before. 2 Muslims were killed during the violence.

A Seleka was killed by suspected Anti-Balaka forces near the Prime Ministers office as he was allegedly about to rob a motorcycle. Muslim militia carried out reprisal attacks against civilians later that day.
Armed Fulani attacked the village of Bolov, in the Batangafo area, killing a former anti-Balaka colonel and another man. MINUSCA elements were alerted and arrived at the village later.

During the night of Feb.14-15 and the next morning gunfire and grenades were heard going off in PK5, a predominantly Muslim neighbourhood, following the killing of a Seleka by Anti-Balaka in the capital. Muslim militiamen killed 2 civilians in Pk5 neighborhood in retaliation the same evening.
Chadian rebels reportedly killed 3 Central Africans and 3 Congolese near Bakporo, CAR.
Leaders of some political parties, including the AFDT, ACDP, CPAPs and UPPRN, and their supporters marched to call for peace and demand full implementation of UN Security Council resolutions.

Parts of the Muslim community protested against the eviction of a Seleka officer who had been offering them protection by international forces. They set up 'roadblocks that restricted the movement of more than 10 humanitarian vehicles.'
An old man was found dead near Bornu. Weapons fire was heard in the area the day before. Residents of the area believe former Seleka were behind the killing.

Around 100 young people armed with Kalashnikovs and knives gathered outside the Central Mosque IDP site and threatened to attack the displaced there following the death of one of their friends whom they accused the displaced of killing.

notes: Residents of Bambari marched to demand a return to normal for their city, and the departure of Seleka General Ali Darassa. Sangaris and MINUSCA forces were present to ensure the safety of those involved.
Public sector students protested, demanding the government respect their right to education.
At least 3 people were killed and several others injured in attacks by armed Mbarara Fulani from the Kabo region on villages in the region of Kaga Bandoro.
A young girl was reportedly abused by Ugandan soldiers based in Obo. [women targeted: girls]
A pastor, his wife and 4 other residents of a village in the north of the country were abducted. All were released the next day except for the pastor.
An unidentified group of youths killed a woman they believed was a witch. Police are seeking the suspects. [women targeted: accused of witchcraft/sorcery]
A protest march against the abduction of the Minister of Youth and Sports was held by various sports federations and youth associations.

actor2: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa
source: RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka
notes: 4 vehicles carrying FPRC elements of the Seleka threatened a consultation delegation escorted by 21 Sangaris vehicles in Bamingui near Ndele. An Operation Sangaris helicopter was sent to intercept the armed men and fired shots. The rebels mention that the shots left two killed and four injured among civilians, and destroyed 4 vehicles, while the Sangaris say no casualty was reported.
28 people were kidnapped near Nzako. There were 9 unidentified men who attacked the people before capturing them and demanding a ransom.
8 people were killed in an attack on Agoudou-manga village, and another 4 in Mbrobaga village, both near Bambari, encouraging residents from Bambari, Ngakobo and Kouango to flee.

'9 people were killed in attacks by armed groups in Botto village (Nana Grebizi Province).'
People demonstrated in support of the consultation team which arrived in Bambari, at the same time as a counter-protest against the consultations.

Muslim youths protested against the arrival of a consultation team. The youths looted the home of the Prefect of Ouaka and took a company car. Weapons fire was also heard, although no injuries were reported.
Former Seleka and armed Fulani attacked villages in the Nana Gribizi region, killing at least 5 and injuring others.

assoc_actor_2: Government of the Central African Republic (2014-2016); RJ: Revolution and Justice
source: RCA (Central African Republic); Centrafrique Presse Info; AP; Radio Ndeke Luka; The New Humanitarian; AFP

actor1: FPRC: Popular Front for the Renaissance of Central Africa

About 400 Muslims protested in Bangui to express their dissatisfaction at being excluded from the reconciliation process.

actor2: EUFOR RCA: European Union Force in the Central African Republic (2014-)

assoc_actor_2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: An Iraqi UN staff member who works for MINUSCA was kidnapped by the Anti-Balaka. She was released the following day.

actor2: EUFOR RCA: European Union Force in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: A Spanish convoy of the EUFOR-RCA force exchanged fire with an armed man and a Muslim militia in Bangui. The armed man was shot and injured and one minor injury on the part of the armed Muslims reported.
Anti-Balaka protested the arrest of General Andjilo on the 18th and 19th January 2015 in Boy-Rabe. Several witnesses reported kidnapping attempts and robberies.
The brother of Pachomius Pabandji, a well known journalist, was beaten and kidnapped by unidentified men, close to where the Iraqi MINUSCA employee was taken.

A female French aid worker who was working for the Catholic medical organisation CODIS was kidnapped alongside a local co-worker by the Anti-Balaka when they seized their vehicle. They were later released on 23/01/2014.
Anti-Balaka protested the arrest of General Andjilo on the 18th and 19th January 2015 in Boy-Rabe. Several witnesses reported kidnapping attempts and robberies, and reports of one death on the 18th.

People protested in Berberati to express their anger against the Congolese contingent of MINUSCA, which they feel does not help prevent crime. This event followed the recent killing of a hunter by unidentified individuals.

actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: A firefight broke out between the Anti-Balaka and the Cameroonian contingent of MINUSCA, which resulted in MINUSCA arresting General Andjilo of the Anti-Balaka.
A hunter was shot dead and his body burned by a group of unidentified people. Witnesses claim that the attackers were Sudanese.
Sixteen people were killed in the village of Konga, in Kouango, by a group believed to be ex-Seleka. Several houses were also burned.
Staff of the Association of Muslims of Africa NGO protested outside their building to demand the payment of salary arrears. They blocked to entrance to prevent the head of the NGO from entering.

In the village of Beboi 4, 38km from Paoua, a group of men beat to death a village leader who had just returned to the village, having been in Cameroon since 2013. They accused him of betraying them and being an accomplice of the ex-Seleka.

assoc_actor_1: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
notes: Around a hundred police auxiliaries protested in Bangui calling for the revision of their status to be fully integration to the national forces.

A large crowd of people protested at the Sangaris base in Bria, calling for their removal from CAR. The demonstrators reportedly trew rocks and grenades at Sangaris forces, while the Sangaris were said to have fired shots to disperse them. The demonstrators erected barricades throughout the town and took control of the aerodrome the following two days.
Around 30 people were assaulted by armed Anti-Balaka. Sangaris intervened to stop the beatings.

Further clashes between two Anti-Balaka groups. One death reported.
Armed groups reportedly based in Cameroon attacked Boyango village, west of Koui (Ouham Pende Province). One person was killed and another injured, and houses were burned.
Fulani herders attack health workers at Ndogoli village, 176km from Bouar, killing one and injuring others. One health worker remains missing as of 10th January 2015.
A hunter was shot and beaten to death by an unidentified armed group 30km from Obo.

Five people were killed and several injured between 6th and 7th of January 2015 in clashes in Bambari between two Anti-Balaka groups. It is reported that the victims were, for the most part, Anti-Balaka.
Following the clashes in Bambari, some Anti-Balaka went to the house of a local community leader and killed him, accusing him of betraying them. The attackers also burned his house.

Five people were killed and several injured between 6th and 7th of January 2015 in clashes in Bambari between two Anti-Balaka groups. It is reported that the victims were, for the most part, Anti-Balaka.
Fulani herders set fire to homes in Boyo village, in revenge for a confrontation with Anti-Balaka.
Arrests: An LRA commander named Dominic Ongwen was arrested by former Seleka forces and handed over to US forces in Haute-Kotto.
Fulani herders set fire to Bomian village.
Fulani herders set fire to Gbanto village.
Ex-Seleka and Fulani attack Mengue village, 7km from Batangafo, killing one and injuring a number of others.
Fulani herders set fire to Ngoumbo village.
In Kolo village, Anti-Balaka bury alive a woman and her child, as she had been accused of witchcraft by one of her husbands other wives.
Ex-Seleka and Fulani attack Mbali village, killing five.

A member of the Anti-Balaka shot dead two brothers from whom he had bought fuel by the roadside and owed money to.
Following the events of the previous day, Muslims held anti-French protests across Bambari, erecting barricades.

source: Radio Ndeke Luka; RCA (Central African Republic)
notes: The Muslim community of Bornou neighbourhood erected barriers and threw stones at a Sangaris patrol, as they did not want them to patrol Bornou. At least one death and two injuries as a result.
