Clashes between Anti-Balaka and Peul militia in Bambari over two days. Large numbers of Peuls, Muslims and Selekas reportedly arrived in the town following the clashes, raising fears among populations.
Two ex-Seleka killed by Anti-Balaka members.

notes: A group of Mbororo reportedly attacked the community of Bahr, CAR, early in the morning. They reportedly killed 3 civilians and injured 2 others, and set fire to around 40 households. The assailants also looted the community shop.

In late November 2014 a Peuhl man was attacked by the Anti-Balaka when he tried to leave Carnot at night with his wife to flee to Cameroon. The attackers tried to cut off his hand, broke the bones of his feet with machetes, and the next morning slit his throat, killing him.
Thirty elements of the LRA kidnapped several people, including children, from the village of Fode. 15 abductees later managed to escape.

actor1: PCUD: Central African Party for Unity and Development
notes: The Anti-Balaka announced officially its commitment to abandoning the armed struggle with a view to transforming its armed wing into a political organisation. The movement therefore transformed itself into a political movement, which is to be known henceforth as the Central African Party for Unity and Development (PCUD).
A man suspected by the Anti-Balaka of being an ex-Seleka fighter left the Carnot enclave to visit the town center. Anti-Balaka captured and lynched him near the market.

One prisoner died during the riot and 13 were injured, while one MINUSCA peacekeeper was seriously wounded, and six others injured.

actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)

Armed Muslims attacked the population of Zemio, notably the Christians. Several houses belonging to Christians were ransacked and burned, and gunshots were heard. Three people were killed and 13 wounded. Many residents have fled to the bush.
Unknown gunmen abduct three Seleka and kill one of them, leaving his body near Radio ama in Bangui. One managed to escape, while the other was injured.
Students of the National School of the Arts staged a protest to demand that the government pay nine months of scholarships arrears, and to denounce the poor conditions of in the institution.

Armed Fulani herders demanded that residents of Balenguere village give them food. When they refused, they attacked the village, killing two people, and taking others hostage. Several injuries also reported.

Gunfire was heard in Baboua, causing the residents to flee and take refuge in the bush. The perpetrators remain unknown.
Fulani members of ex-Seleka kill a man.
Gunmen believed to be Funali and ex-Seleka attack the village of Yamale on the 21st and 22nd October 2014, killing at least thirty, and wounding dozens of others.
Residents of Batangafo were forced to flee to a nearby IDP site when ex-Seleka entered the area, firing into the air. They shot one individual in the leg, and proceeded to loot homes.
Gunmen believed to be Funali and ex-Seleka attack the village of Yamale on the 21st and 22nd October 2014, killing at least thirty, and wounding dozens of others.
A grenade thrown by Anti-Balaka exploded at Guitangola market, injuring two.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and armed Fulani.
Anti-Balaka murdered five people in the villages of Bangao and Bomballa, accusing them of collaborating with ex-Seleka.

Anti-Balaka were attending a funeral in Bolokpaka village. They shot into the air as part of the ceremony. Ex-Seleka based 2km away felt threatened by this, and thus they entered Bolokpaka village, and killed three people.

assoc_actor_2: Christian Group (Central African Republic); Civilians (Central African Republic)
notes: Anti-Balaka abducted a Belgian religious man leading Caritas NGO and some of his colleagues in Fafara village near Kaga Bandoro. They were released soon after, but the assailants took away their vehicle and property.
Anti-Balaka retaliated to the ex-Seleka attack on Bolokpaka, and attacked the ex-Seleka, killing three.
Anti-Balaka murdered five people in the villages of Bangao and Bomballa, accusing them of collaborating with ex-Seleka. In Bangao they set fire to coffee plantations.
Anti-Balaka attacked a Muslim who was riding a motorcycle, killing him.
In retaliation for the killing of a Muslim in PK5 by Anti-Balaka, Muslims opened fire on residents of the nearby Bea Rex Christian neighborhood, killing two and seriously injuring another.
Anti-Balaka detonate a grenade, injuring three civilians.
Suspected Fulani militiamen killed 14 people and burned down 32 homes in Botobadjia village in Bambari.
In a village near central Kouango, ex-Seleka publicly executed two men on suspicion of treason and belonging to the Anti-Balaka.

actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: Clashes between MINUSCA and Anti-Balaka. Six Anti-Balaka killed as a result, and four UN peacekeepers wounded.
Anti-Balaka set up barricades in Bangui.
Two people were killed, five wounded and 27 homes burned in a Fulani attack on Sangarigou village.

A member of the Anti-Balaka was caught and stoned by residents of Ouango, who were angered by recent abuses and looting in the area. This led to clashes between the two groups. Three residents are also killed in the violence.
Anti-Balaka attacks Ousmane Mahamat Ousmane, member of ex-Seleka and former minister, as he leaves his house, but his body guards defended him.
Looting: Anti-Balaka loot the police station in Petevo.
Anti-Balaka pillage 12 houses: 8 belonging to civilians and 4 belonging to military personnel.

actor1: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Gendarmerie
assoc_actor_1: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
notes: Following the looting of houses by Anti-Balaka, the gendarmerie and the police exchange fire with them.

actor1: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
notes: Father Mateusz Dziedzic, the pastor of Baboua, of Polish nationality, was abducted by members of the FDPC of Abdoulaye Miskine. They are demanding the release of their leader. He was later released on 26th November 2014, along with 15 Cameroonians who had been kidnapped on other occasions. It is assumed, but not confirmed, that this was arranged in return for the release of Abdoulaye Miskine.

actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: Anti-Balaka clashed with French military and a Burundian convoy of UN peacekeepers in Bangui, resulting in 6 deaths.

assoc_actor_2: EUFOR RCA: European Union Force in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: A Sangaris patrol was targeted by armed Muslims, who attacked them. A Spanish contingent of EUFOR-RCA came and opened fire to disperse the attackers, injuring two.

assoc_actor_1: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: Sangaris and MINUSCA responded to attack by ex-seleka on an IDP camp; killing six on the side of ex-Seleka.
Women associated with ex-Seleka visited the IDP site at the Catholic Church to get some provisions. They were attacked by some of the IDPs.
300 unarmed youths peacefully protested at the runway at the airport in Bangui to demand the resignation of transitional President Catherine Samba-Panza.

actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: An armed group opened fire on a UN patrol monitoring a protest, wounding six officers.

In response to the assault of women of ex-Seleka at the IDP camp, ex-Seleka attacked the IDP camp, killing nine people and wounding others. They killed a further five as they fled, and abducted two people as guides, who have been missing since.

actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: An armed group attack a convoy of Pakistani and Bangladeshi UN peacekeepers, killing a Pakistani peacekeeper. Another peacekeeper was severely wounded, and seven more were injured.

Youths of Kpetene in Bangui barricaded their localities and prevented the Sangaris from entering. They believe that Sangaris should be focusing on disarming individuals in the Km5 area instead. Stones were thrown at Sangaris troops, and Sangaris used a taser on one individual.

Youths of Bea-Rex neighbourhoods in Bangui barricaded their localities and prevented the Sangaris from entering. They believe that Sangaris should be focusing on disarming individuals in the Km5 area instead. Stones were thrown at Sangaris troops, and Sangaris used a taser on one individual.
Muslim protestors loot and destroy kiosks near the MINUSCA headquarters.

assoc_actor_1: SCTB: Union of Drivers and Conductors of Taxis and Taxi-Buses
notes: The union of taxi and bus drivers begins a strike following the killing of a taxi driver. They barricaded the streets of Boganda, Martyrs and Koudoukou.
Anti-Balaka fighters paraded through the streets, showing off their weapons and shooting into the air.

Anti-Balaka ambushed a car on the Bambari-Ndasima road. There were 24 people in the car, both Christians and Muslims. Seven Muslim passengers were killed, and the rest survived. The Anti-Balaka captured the remaining people, both Christians and Muslims, and they let all of the Christians go, including the driver. All of the Muslim men whom they caught were killed. They undressed their bodies, and cut them into pieces.
Clashes occur between Anti-Balaka and armed Muslims in Km5. No deaths reported.

source: RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka
notes: KM5 militia killed at least seven civilians, injured 25, and fired shots in the air and looted and burned properties along Boganda avenue in retaliation for the lynching of a Seleka in Gobongo the day before.

An ex-Seleka man who threw the grenades in Bangui was later chased and killed by youths. His body was tied to the taxi which he had hijacked, then dragged up to Gobongo market where it was burnt. Sangaris forces intervened to extinguish the fire and establish security.
An element of ex-Seleka in a taxi threw a grenade at passers by on Independence Avenue and PK10 in Bangui, killing 4 people including a pregnant woman and wounding others.

actor2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: Clashes occurred between MINUSCA and Anti-Balaka led by Andilo.

actor2: Military Forces of Cameroon (1982-) Rapid Intervention Battalion
notes: Clashes occur between Anti-Balaka and the Rapid Intervention Brigade of Cameroon, resulting in one death on the Cameroonian side. These clashes were in retaliation to the beating of a Central African woman who was in custody in Cameroon by the Rapid Intervention Bridgade.
At least three killed and four injured by unidentified gunmen in two separate incidents in the 3rd and 4th arrondissements of Bangui.
More than 200 boda boda riders protested against violence targeting them in the capital.

Following the Anti-Balaka attack on a vehicle carrying Muslim civilians, young Muslims retaliated, and went to the IDP camp in Bambari looking for Anti-Balaka to seek revenge. An estimated 17 people are killed in this attack on the IDP camp, which continued into the following day, while French and African forces attempt to intervene to restore calm.
Students from the University of Bangui went on strike and barricaded Avenue des Martyrs to demand that the restaurant in the university resume activities.
Suspected former Anti-Balaka gunmen killed a boda driver in Damala Don Bosco of Bangui.

source: Radio Ndeke Luka; RCA (Central African Republic)
notes: Following the Anti-Balaka attack on a vehicle carrying Fulani civilians, ex-Seleka retaliated, and went to the IDP camp in Bambari looking for Anti-Balaka to seek revenge. At least 16 people were killed in the attack, while French and African forces attempt to intervene to restore calm.
A motorcycle taxi driver was killed by Anti-Balaka.

assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of Central African Republic (2014-2016) Border Guard
notes: A border officer was killed by unknown gunmen at his home in Bangui around midnight.

source: Radio Ndeke Luka; RCA (Central African Republic)
notes: At least two Fulanis killed in an attack by Anti-Balaka on their vehicle on the Ndassima axis, 30km from Bambari. The gunmen also burned the vehicle. This incident led to retaliatory attacks by ex-Seleka the next day on displaced populations of Bambari.

assoc_actor_2: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: Clashes took place between Anti-Balaka and Sangaris and the Gabonese contingent MINUSCA during an attempted disarmament. Two deaths reported on the side of Anti-Balaka.
Clashes in KM5 over two days between Muslim and non-Muslim gunmen who committed lootings in several neighborhoods of Bangui left one person killed and several houses burned.

Members of the armed branch of the Revolutionary Justice movement (RJ) attacked Pougol village near Paoua in retaliation for having been expelled from the town after racketeering. Several people injured and houses burnt down.

Six members of a single Peulh family, including two children and a woman, were killed in an Anti-Balaka attack on Djimbete Peulh encampment 26km from Bambari in late September. They also burned down the entire encampment.
Clashes in KM5 over two days between Muslim and non-Muslim gunmen who committed lootings in several neighborhoods of Bangui left one person killed and several houses burned.

Sangaris attempted to disarm some armed Muslims. In response, they erected barriers to prevent Sangaris from entering the neighbourhood. Sangris fired deterrent shots, with the rioters responding with gunfire also. No deaths reported.

Seven hunters and a twelve year old were attacked by the LRA 30km from Obo. They kidnapped one hunter and the twelve year old, while the rest escaped. The kidnapped hunter escaped the following morning. The LRA still have the boy.
About 40 attackers, believed to be Anti-Balaka, attacked Mbata village and killed at least ten people, including two women and three children. They also looted, and burned 11 homes.
The Mayor of Ngakobo, was shot dead by three members of ex-Seleka who approached him on a motorcycle.
Five Muslims were killed by Anti-Balaka in the Ngondongo area of Sibut while accompanying a truck of cattle to Bangui.
Elements of the Anti-Balaka under Andjilo set houses of Gbangou village on fire, leaving almost 1,000 people homeless.
Witnesses report between 9 and 25 vehicles of ex-Seleka soldiers arriving in Kaga Bandoro. Reasons for the large ex-Seleka presence currently unknown.

assoc_actor_2: Muslim Group (Central African Republic); Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016) Gendarmerie
notes: A group of men attacked Harouna Rachid Mamouda, an Imam, when he left the Catholic parish to drop off a letter. Local gendarme and UN peacekeepers rescued him.

Following the robbery of Guitangola health centre the previous day by Anti-Balaka, in which one of them was shot and killed, they returned the following evening, fired shots and detonated a grenade at the health centre. A bystander was killed, and many were injured.
Journalist Ulrich Landry Nguema-Ngokpele, director of Le Quotidien newspaper, was attacked by a gang of Anti-Balaka when they became suspicious of his work equipment.

Anti-Balaka broke into Guitangola hospital asking for money. They exchanged gunfire with another, unidentified group, and then looted a small shed at the hospital. One of the thieves, whose identity is currently unknown, was killed.
The parents of the hostages recently taken from Baboua burned tyres to demand that the government dialogue with the captors to secure the release of hostages.
A customs inspector was attacked on his way home from work by Anti-Balaka armed with Kalashnikovs and machetes.

Arrests: Four Anti-Balaka officials, including the spokesperson, head of Military Police, and Chief of Staff were arrested by Sangaris for carrying weapons in their car. They claim the weapons had been confiscated from others while on a field mission. They have been transferred to Ngarangba jail, while Anti-Balaka members say that this event has caused tensions to rise.
Unidentified gunmen raided Banda, 22 km from Rafai. Four people, including a pregnant woman, were killed. Three others were taken hostage.
A woman was shot dead by Fulani. The Fulani had demanded food from her, and she had none to hand over.
15 September. During the month of September, an armed group ordered a young man to masturbate in public in Bangui. After he refused, they severed his genitals and left him to bleed to death.

actor1: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: The authority for the peacekeeping force in CAR formally transitioned to the United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (MINUSCA). The authority was previously held by the African-led International Support Mission in the Central African Republic (MISCA).
Five people were taken hostage and property looted by the LRA in Maboussou village. After traveling a few kilometers, four of the hostages were released. One hostage remains with the LRA.

actor1: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
notes: Eight people were kidnapped 24 km from Baboua by an armed men of Abdoulaye Miskine. The captors are demanding the release of their leader, who is being held in Cameroon, before releasing the hostages.
Two people were killed when gunfire broke out following a misunderstanding between anti-Balaka fighters in Bangui 8e.

actor2: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
assoc_actor_2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014); EUFOR RCA: European Union Force in the Central African Republic (2014-)

actor2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: Surrender/Defect:236 ex-Seleka based in camp RDOT disarmed and left to return home. They were accompanied by a contingent of MISCA.

Dozens of vehicles containing heavily armed Seleka are nearing Bambari, coming from Bria, N'dele and Birao. A Seleka leader claimed that the movement is not, as reported, in preparation for an attack on Bangui.
20 armed Fulanis, belonging to ex-Seleka, killed 14 people in Sindiyassi village, 23 km from Bambari.
Ex-Seleka shot and killed three men, one of them elderly, near a makeshift IDP camp.

source: Radio Ndeke Luka; RCA (Central African Republic)
notes: Clashes between Anti-Balaka and armed Fulani have killed nine people and injured several others. Fulanis were reported to have left the area a week prior, as a large number of Anti-Balaka arrived in the town. After the clashes, they re-took control of the town, and looted a number of properties.

As Sangaris attempt to arrest some members of Anti-Balaka, clashes ensue. Anti-Balaka detonated grenades. Anti-Balaka claim two deaths on their side, while Sangaris claim that there was a single death on the Anti-Balaka side.
Angered by the recent death of a comrade, Anti-Balaka destroyed the house of the mayor and his two deputies, and burned tyres to barricade the road.

actor2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: MISCA attempted to arrest a wanted member of Anti-Balaka. While pursuing him through a market they fired shots, resulting in two serious injuries to bystanders, including a 12 year old girl who was shot in the thigh.
At least five people were killed during an attack on Nana Bakassa by armed men believed to be ex-Seleka.
A man was attacked with machetes by a group of youths in Bozoum. They suspected him of being part of the ex-Seleka contingent that was once in Bozoum.
Fulani attacked a man, his pregnant wife, and her stepfather on suspicion of being Anti-Balaka. The two men were killed, while the woman was injured and lost her baby.

actor1: MINUSCA: United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: Deployment:The advance team of the Rwanda Police peacekeepers, under Rwanda Formed Police Unit One (RWAFPU), arrived in CAR for a one-year peacekeeping mission under the United Nations Multi-dimensional Integrated mission in Central African Republic (Minusca). Rwanda is the first nation to deploy police peacekeepers under MINUSCA.

actor2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: Several people were injured during a shootout between armed militants and MISCA forces in Batangafo
Fighting continued for the third day between Anti-Balaka and Seleka in Boda, Lobaye. At least 50 people were reported killed between Aug 27-29, including 11 on Aug 27.

actor1: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
actor2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: A highway bandit was arrested after a shootout with MISCA about 20km from Baboua. The bandit is believed to be part of the FDPC of Abdoulaye Miskine.
Ex-Seleka at Camp Beal in Bangui protested against their dire living conditions.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and Fulanis have caused the death of at least 11 people and wounded three others. These clashes follow the recent assassination of two Fulanis.
Fighting continued for the second day between Anti-Balaka and Seleka in Boda, Lobaye. At least 50 people were reported killed between Aug 27-29, including 11 on Aug 27.

actor1: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
notes: A vehicle and two motorcycles were set on fire between the villages of Zoukombo and Zoro. Some claim that it is the Democratic Forces of the Central African People (FDPC) of Abdoulaye Miskine that are responsible. The bandits stole about 13m CFA from the driver and passengers.

Fighting broke out between Anti-Balaka and Seleka in Boda, Lobaye, following the killing of 2 young Muslim men by anti-Balaka. At least 50 people were reported killed between Aug 27-29, including 11 on Aug 27.
2 young Muslim men were killed by anti-Balaka in Boda, Lobaye.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and Fulanis have caused the death of at least 11 people and wounded three others. These clashes follow the recent assassination of two Fulanis.
Fighting continued for the second day in Bambari between 2 ex-Seleka factions
Men of ex-Seleka of Fulani ethnicity attempted to kill former area commander of Bria and his aide, who are ethic Goula. They attacked him at his home, but he and his aide escaped.

17 ex-Seleka rebels were killed in a dispute over control of a checkpoint. This dispute saw a group under General Joseph Zoundeko (ethnic Goula) pitted against a group under General Ali Djarras, which is largely composed of ethnic Fulani from the region. The two groups reconciled in the afternoon.

assoc_actor_1: CIONGCA: Inter-Nongovernmental Organisation Council in Central Africa
notes: About 500 people took part in a march in support of the transition process in CAR. Members of CIONGCA (the Non-Governmental Organisation Inter Academy Council in Central Africa) and those of the Association of Parents of Students took part in the walk.

assoc_actor_2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: Clashes between Anti-Balaka and a self-defence group in Cantonnier. Cameroonian elements of MISCA intervene to restore calm. One Anti-Balaka and a woman who was hit by a stray bullet were killed.

Almost one thousand Muslims demonstrated at the MINUSCA headquarters to demand the depature of the French contringent of troops following recent incidences in PK5. A memorandum was presented, describing the facts allegedly suffered by some members of the Muslim community since the date of December 5, 2013.
An IDP site in the Castors neighbourhood was attacked by Muslims. No deaths reported.

assoc_actor_1: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)

A grenade exploded in a cinema hall, causing serious injuries to six people. Two people have been arrested.
Two Fulanis assassinated in a village located 8km from Bambari. This is believed to have caused clashes between Anti-Balaka and Fulanis the week after in Ngakobo.

Clashes between members of the Anti-Balaka in Ndjongo-Mpoko village, Bimbo commune, leaving one member of the group killed as the grenade he was holding exploded. Activities were paralysed in the area and populations fled to the bush.

assoc_actor_1: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: Eight people killed in clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka on the 20th and 21st August 2014. MISCA intervened to try to calm the situation.

actor2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: More than 100 Muslims demonstrate outside the MINUSCA office against the death of a member of their community, who died in the incidents of 19th and 20th August. MISCA Force Commander, Brigadier General Martin chomu Tumenta, spoke with the demonstrators to calm the situation.

actor2: EUFOR RCA: European Union Force in the Central African Republic (2014-)
assoc_actor_2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: During a demonstration, EUFOR, with support from MISCA, intervened to separate demonstrators. Extremist and criminal elements, which mixed with the crowd, started to shoot. Nine people were injured.
At least three killed and several injured in a grenade explosion as gunmen clashed at a bar in Begoua commune.

assoc_actor_1: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)

actor2: EUFOR RCA: European Union Force in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: Clashes between French troops of EUFOR and gunmen from the KM5 neighborhood of Bangui over two days. At least five deaths reported, including a Red Cross volunteer who was trying to help the injured.
Seven traders from Bakala were arrested by ex-Seleka on patrol in Morouba. They were tortured for having not paid a sum of money demanded by the gunmen.
The site of the Orange mobile phone network was raided by armed people believed to be ex-Seleka. Technical equipment was stolen, resulting in a lack of network coverage in Bambari.
At least 34 civilians killed in several villages in the Mbres region by ex-Seleka and armed Fulani between 13th and 15th August 2014.

103 children aged 8 to 17 were released over the past week from armed groups in Bangui following negotiations with armed group leaders. The 103 children, 13 of whom are girls, were associated with Anti-Balaka groups.
At least 34 civilians killed in several villages in the Mbres region by ex-Seleka and armed Fulani between 13th and 15th August 2014.
At least 34 civilians killed in several villages in the Mbres region by ex-Seleka and armed Fulani between 13th and 15th August 2014.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka in Begoua around 12 August, paralysing activities in the area for several days. No mentioned fatalities.
Thousands of people took part in a peace march in Bangui.

Two groups of Anti-Balaka (one under General Andiyo, and the other under Olivier Koudemon aka Gbangouma) clash from the 8th August until the following morning. Two deaths reported, and a number of residents are injured in the cross-fire while attempting to flee.
A woman was killed by relatives of a deceased individual, who accused her of witchcraft, resulting in the death of their relative. [women targeted: accused of witchcraft/sorcery]

actor2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: While people queued at a bank to collect their wages, they felt angered that the bank clerks were not doing their work properly and for planning to close early. The group smashed the glass door of the bank. This prompted MISCA to react by firing to disperse the crowd. One man was shot in the arm.

Two groups of Anti-Balaka (one under General Andiyo, and the other under Olivier Koudemon aka Gbangouma) clash from the 8th August until the following morning. Two deaths reported, and a number of residents are injured in the cross-fire while attempting to flee.
People demonstrate to demand the return of Andre Nzapayeke as Prime Minister.

assoc_actor_2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: Clashes continue for a second day between Sangaris and ex-Seleka. 60 deaths, including two MISCA soldiers from DRC, and two Sangaris soldiers injured between 4th and 5th August 2014.

assoc_actor_1: OFCA: Organization of Central African Republic Women
notes: Almost 3,000 women and youths gathered on Barthelemy Buganda Avenue, organised by OFCA, in protest against the possible inclusion of members of the armed groups in the upcoming government.

assoc_actor_2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: According to Sangaris, they were attacked by 100 heavily armed ex-Seleka. Ex-Seleka accuse the French soldiers of opening fire first and bringing with them Anti-Balaka fighters. 60 deaths, including two MISCA soldiers from DRC, and two Sangaris soldiers injured between 4th and 5th August 2014.
Explosions and gunfire were heard in Bangui 3e and 5e, causing a number of people to flee.
Clashes continued between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka in Batangafo. At least 22 people (mainly civilians) were killed during fighting on 30-31/07.

Ceasefire/Peacetalks:Captain Gilbert Kamezou-lai of the Anti-Balaka announced in Bangui the dissolution of the Anti-Balaka, following the recent ceasefire agreement. According to him, all Anti-Balaka must respect this statement, otherwise they will be 'treated like bandits' by security forces.
Ex-Seleka are attacked, resulting in the deaths of many. They believe the attackers to be Anti-Balaka. At least 22 people (mainly civilians) were killed during fighting on 30-31/07.
The Revolutionary Justice group claimed that armed men attacked some of their members in a vehicle in Paoua, resulting in 1 dead and 4 injured.
Surrender/Defect:Approximately 200 out of 800 members of ex-Seleka based in Camp RDOT agreed to and began disarming and returning to their respective villages on 29th July 2014.
A spokesman for ex-Seleka claimed that the recent ceasefire has been 'broken' after its fighters came under attack from the Anti-Balaka near Grimari.

Ceasefire/Peacetalks:The military wing of the former Seleka rebel coalition stated that it does not recognise the ceasefire agreement signed last week in Brazzaville, according to a statement by Seleka military chief General Joseph Zoundeko.
Seven people were kidnapped and killed between 24th and 26th July 2014 in Bambari while crossing the River Ouaka bridge. Sources say that Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka are behind the killings.

actor2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: Surrender/Defect:MISCA begin to voluntarily disarm ex-Seleka at Camp RDOT.
A member of ex-Seleka from Camp RDOT was abducted from Gobongo market. Witnesses blame Anti-Balaka for the abduction.
Seven people were kidnapped and killed between 24th and 26th July 2014 in Bambari while crossing the River Ouaka bridge. Sources say that Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka are behind the killings.
Seven people were kidnapped and killed between 24th and 26th July 2014 in Bambari while crossing the River Ouaka bridge. Sources say that Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka are behind the killings.
Anti Balaka forces are accused of attacking Muslims in Dekoa and Boda.
Anti Balaka forces are accused of attacking Muslims in Dekoa and Boda.
About 80 LRA rebels attacked three hunters 20km from Obo. They fired shots at the hunters, who managed to escape.

Following the killing of an ex-Seleka by Anti-Balaka, allies of the victim began looting and robbing stores, firing off shots and took a group of students captive. A father of one of the students was stabbed when he tried to follow the group.
Anti-Balaka kill a member of ex-Seleka who was on his way to get breakfast.

actor1: FDPC: Democratic Front for the People of the Central African Republic
notes: Three vehicles and five motorcycles carrying people and goods were held up and robbed by armed men of the rebel leader Miskine. The 15 assailants were armed with Kalashnikovs and rocket launchers. Travellers were taken to the bush where their possessions were stolen.

assoc_actor_1: Students (Central African Republic); Teachers (Central African Republic)
notes: Students of the Normal School of Teachers in Bambari organised a walk from the hotel to the academic inspection center to file a strike notice. They are demanding the payment of eight months unpaid scholarships.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka. Nine people, including eight civilians and one ex-Seleka killed.
LRA rebels attack and abduct a group of hunters 20km from Obo. The hunters were stripped of all their belongings before being released the next morning.
Clashes continue between Anti-Balaka under the leadership of Andiyo and those under the leadership of Mazimbelet (both of the 4th arrondissement). No deaths reported.

Clashes between Anti-Balaka under the leadership of Andiyo and those under the leadership of Mazimbelet (both of the 4th arrondissement). No deaths reported. Mazimbelets home was ransacked, but he had fled.
Ex-Seleka attack and burn Gbabanda village, killing three.

assoc_actor_1: OFCA: Organization of Central African Republic Women; Women (Central African Republic)
notes: Nearly a thousand women of OFCA staged a public protest at the headquarters of OFCA, demanding that victims of the conflict are represented at the talks in Brazzaville.
A young Muslim was murdered in Carnot hospital.

In July 2014, Anti-Balaka captured 34 Peuhl herders near Ngbaina as they tried to reach Cameroon with their cattle. They beat them, stole their cattle, and threatened to kill them if they did not pay US$3,750 ransom. Three months later, they were released when relatives in Cameroon organised to pay a reduced ransom. The Anti-Balaka took all but one of the Peuhl herders to Yaloke. The remamining man had not yet been released as of December 2014.

Seven teachers have been killed or kidnapped in the space of a month (July 2014) in Bambari and its surroundings. The teachers were killed or kidnapped in the villages of Liwa (10km Bambari), Goyali (60km from the city) and Gbotto-Bgandjia (on the Bambari-Alindao road).

Seven teachers have been killed or kidnapped in the space of a month (July 2014) in Bambari and its surroundings. The teachers were killed or kidnapped in the villages of Liwa (10km Bambari), Goyali (60km from the city) and Gbotto-Bgandjia (on the Bambari-Alindao road).

Seven teachers have been killed or kidnapped in the space of a month (July 2014) in Bambari and its surroundings. The teachers were killed or kidnapped in the villages of Liwa (10km Bambari), Goyali (60km from the city) and Gbotto-Bgandjia (on the Bambari-Alindao road).

actor2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: 300 students, dressed in black as a sign of mourning, organised a march to claim the right to education. The peaceful march was dispersed by the elements of Misca who fired shots and tear gas on them, to the dismay of demonstrators who wanted to submit a memorandum to the Head of State. Several students injured, including one who fell unconscious.
A member of the Anti-Balaka stopped outside the ex-Seleka camp RDOT. He brandished his machete. Ex-Seleka killed him.

assoc_actor_2: EUFOR RCA: European Union Force in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: Anti-Balaka, angered at the recent killing of a comrade, surround the ex-Seleka Camp RDOT. Shots were fired. Sangaris and EUFOR disperse the group.
The former president of CAR, Michel Djotodia, who led the rebel Seleka militia that swept him to power in 2013, was renamed head of the movement during a meeting in Birao.
A member of ex-Seleka was killed by Anti-Balaka behind their Campt RDOT base. On the same day, a member of ex-Seleka was killed by Anti-Balaka when he went to pay for food.

assoc_actor_1: RJ: Revolution and Justice; APRD: Popular Army for the Restoration of the Republic and Democracy
source: RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka
notes: A group of unarmed people dressed in military uniform, reportedly former fighters of the Popular Army for the Restoration of Democracy (APRD) and part of the Revolutionary Justice movement, walked peacefully from Yaloke to Bossembele with a banner en route to Bangui as part of a protest against their living conditions, in order to meet with the transitional authorities. They were stopped near Bossembele town by the Department of Defence to hear their reasons for the peaceful march.

assoc_actor_1: APRD: Popular Army for the Restoration of the Republic and Democracy
notes: A group of unarmed people dressed in military uniform, reportedly former fighters of the Popular Army for the Restoration of Democracy (APRD), arrived from Bozoum and walked peacefully through Yaloke with a banner en route to Bangui as part of a protest against their living conditions, in order to meet with the transitional authorities. The group was 78 large when it began, but was over 300 strong when it reached Yaloke.

assoc_actor_2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: Clashes between an armed group and Sangaris and MISCA. Four deaths on the side of the armed group.

actor2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: Following the shooting of an Anti-Balaka by MISCA, Anti-Balaka take to the streets, erect barricades, and burn tyres. MISCA fire shots in the air to disperse the militia.

actor1: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: MISCA chased some people into the bush for playing cards illegally. An element of MISCA opened fire on the players they pursued, killing one.
A woman was raped by an armed gang in her home. They also looted the house. Local inhabitants blame Anti-Balaka for the attack.

actor2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: MISCA approach Anti-Balaka with the intent of disarming them. Clashes occur, resulting in the death of one Anti-Balaka.

assoc_actor_2: UN: United Nations; Aid Workers (Central African Republic)
notes: A convoy of eight humanitarian UN workers were stopped outside Boali, abducted and held by armed elements for a few hours. Following negotiations, the staff were released.
After the killing of a local resident by MISCA, angry residents brought his body to the MISCA base in order to protest against his killing.

Anti-Balaka invaid nine villages in Mbres prefecture of Nana Gribizi, forcing 12,000 civilians to flee to the bush. They say they are tracking Seleka militiamen, and will mistreat suspected supporters of the group.
Anti-Balaka militiamen attack Hadji district, killing two Muslim civilians.

26 civilians were killed and 35 injured in an ex-Seleka attack on an IDP camp in the grounds of a church. Witnesses blame ex-Seleka, while ex-Seleka claim it was Muslims who were angered at the recent killing of two Muslims by Anti-Balaka.
The LRA carried out an attack in Kpangou, a village located 100 km from Nzako. Several persons have been taken hostage by the rebels and possessions of the local population have been looted.

actor2: AU-RTF: African Union-led Regional Task Force (2011-)
notes: Surrender/Defect:Ugandan troops of the Regional Task Force begin a disarmament of ex-Seleka troops.
A motorbike taxi driver encountered a group of ex-Seleka. They arrested him, took away his motorbike and tortured him to death.

assoc_actor_1: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014); Military Forces of France (2012-2017)
assoc_actor_2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014); Military Forces of France (2012-2017)
source: Radio Ndeke Luka; RCA (Central African Republic)
notes: Clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka following the killing of a motorcycle taxi driver, left at least four people killed. Dozens injured and lootings also reported in the town. Sangaris and MISCA soldiers intervened to calm the situation down.
Anti-Balaka abducts two village chiefs on the Kaga Bandoro axis as part of their progression to track Seleka militiamen, asking for a ransom of 100,000 CFA francs each.

assoc_actor_1: APRD: Popular Army for the Restoration of the Republic and Democracy
notes: A group of unarmed people dressed in military uniform, reportedly former fighters of the Popular Army for the Restoration of Democracy (APRD), walked peacefully through Bozoum with a banner en route to Bangui as part of a protest against their living conditions, in order to meet with the transitional authorities.
Anti-Balaka apprehend a suspected thief and bury him alive.

actor2: EUFOR RCA: European Union Force in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: Looting: 14 Anti-Balaka were arrested by EUFOR and held in the Department of Research and Investigation because they were suspected of being responsible for cases of looting of the homes of local inhabitants.

actor2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: Anti-Balaka erected barricades on Avenue des Martyrs due to discontent with the arrest of 14 comrades by EUFOR. They were later dispersed by MISCA and Sangaris.
During a prayer, an armed gang detonated grenades into a mosque. 34 people were injured.

Between 30th June and 3rd July 2014, the LRA attack the villages of Taguia, Nambo and Kamanda, resulting in the wounding of one person, and the abduction of 11 others. 10 of the captives, who were abducted from Kamanda on 3rd July, were later released on 7th July 2014.

source: RCA (Central African Republic); Radio Ndeke Luka
notes: Following Sangariss firing into the air to disperse a group of youth who were throwing stones at them, Anti-Balaka then threw a grenade at Sangaris, resulting in clashes between the two groups. Seven Sangaris soldiers injured and one Anti-Balaka arrested.

During a strike by students of the University of Bangui, a vehicle of the Italian NGO COOPI was pelted with stones by the students as it approached a barricade they had erected, causing several injuries to those travelling in the vehicle.
Residents of Berberati organised a protest march to express their dissatisfaction with abuses by armed groups based in their locality.
After raiding a market in Kouki, ex-Seleka and armed Muslims clash with Anti-Balaka. Three abductees escaped. Death toll, if any, currently unknown.
Ex-Seleka and armed Muslims storm a market, fire shots at civilians, abduct three people and loot. They torture and kill one man who tried to escape.
Members of the Muslim community of Bambari staged a peaceful march to promote peace and social cohesion in Ouaka and the city of Bambari.
Eight people were killed and several injured between 30th June and 2nd July 2014 in Batangafo by ex-Seleka.
Three people were killed and another wounded during an attack by ex-Seleka on Ngakobo village, near Bambari, according to MISCA.
Eight people were killed and several injured between 30th June and 2nd July 2014 in Batangafo by ex-Seleka.

Between 30th June and 3rd July 2014, the LRA attack the villages of Taguia, Nambo and Kamanda, resulting in the wounding of one person, and the abduction of 11 others. 10 of the captives, who were abducted from Kamanda on 3rd July, were later released on 7th July 2014.
Bembere Camp for Sudanese refugees was attacked. The refugees were beaten with fists and rifle butts and their money, mobiles and livestock were looted.
The bodies of a man and a woman were pulled from the Ouaka River. The victims had been beheaded. Exact time of death and perpetrators currently unknown.
Eight people were killed and several injured between 30th June and 2nd July 2014 in Batangafo by ex-Seleka.

Between 30th June and 3rd July 2014, the LRA attacks the villages of Taguia, Nambo and Kamanda, resulting in the wounding of one person, and the abduction of 11 others. 10 of the captives, who were abducted from Kamanda on 3rd July, were later released on 7th July 2014.
A lieutenant of ex-Seleka from Camp RDOT was arrested and killed by Anti-Balaka when he went to visit family in Gobongo.

actor2: AU-RTF: African Union-led Regional Task Force (2011-)
notes: Clashes between ex-Seleka and Ugandan troops of the AU Regional Task Force on the LRA in Kono village, Nzako. At least 15 ex-Seleka killed, and several Ugandan troops reported dead. Initial reports state that the AU-RTF mistook the ex-Seleka for LRA.
According to local sources, false Anti-Balaka (group purporting to be Anti-Balaka) destroyed the house of a Muslim man.

Following the destroying of a local Muslims house by 'false' Anti-Balaka (group purporting to be Anti-Balaka), a local self-defense group clashed with these armed men, resulting in three serious injuries.

Reprisal violence erupts in Bambari between 23rd and 26th July 2014, in which 82 people die, following the attack by Anti-Balaka on Muslim Fulani in Liwa. These sectarian attacks have occurred between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka, as well as smaller groups. The attacks involved clashes between these groups, in addition to attacks on civilians.

These sectarian attacks have occurred between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka, as well as smaller groups. The attacks involved clashes between these groups, in addition to attacks on civilians.
Shots fired between Anti-Balaka and Sangaris. No deaths on the side of Sangaris. Death toll, if any, currently unknown on the side of Anti-Balaka.

notes: Surrender/Defect:A top LRA commander, Sam Opio, defected to the Uganda troops of the Regional Task Force in Obo region. 10 abductees, including seven children, were also rescued.

Anti-Balaka attack Liwa village in Bambari, killing 17 Fulani.

actor2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: Anti-Balaka attack MISCA in Boda.

actor1: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
notes: Anti-Balaka attack the police station in Bimbo, beating a policeman and ransacking the office.
Ex-Seleka attack civilians in Sabanga, a village a few kilometers from Bakala. Five members of one family were killed, including a 7-year-old girl and 12-year-old boy.

A member of Anti-Balaka assaulted a woman after she could not hand over money that he demanded from her. She died from her injuries. Other members of Anti-Balaka are looking for the perpetrator to punish him.
Villagers from Ndachima, 35km from Bambari, killed a Fulani herder and stole his motorbike.
Following the killing of a Fulani herder, Fulanis attack Ndachima, killing between 3 and 10 people.
Five people kidnapped by the LRA at Kono gold mine, and nearby homes looted.

Students of the Faculty of Arts and Humanities of Bangui University demonstrated by burning tyres, banging on doors and windows and blocking the entrance to the rectory. They are demanding a rethink of the LMD requirements for achieving bachelors, masters and doctorates.

A reconciliation process begins between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka. They sign a document to formalise this process. A first meeting is held, in which a mediator is appointed - Blessed Kouyate, a Guinean man, the coordinator of the NGO Pareto.
Anti-Balaka attack Ouandedje village, 15km from Bambari, killing two men who were on a motorbike - a member of ex-Seleka, and a Fulani herder.
Three people killed by the LRA in Wagou village, 10km from Zabe, and 25 people were kidnapped.

actor1: EUFOR RCA: European Union Force in the Central African Republic (2014-)
notes: EUFOR RCA reaches full operational capacity, now including 700 soldiers and gendarmes from France, Spain, Estonia, Finland, Georgia, Latvia, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Poland and Romania.
Two Sudanese residents of the Bembere refugee camp were shot dead, and three others were wounded by militiamen.
In Kajbi gold mine, near Morobanda, Anti-Balaka buried a man alive and killed another with a machete for speaking to ex-Seleka.

Armed Muslims from Pk5 confronted some Muslim men believed to have been involved in the recent killing and robbery of a Cameroonian businessman. The groups clashed and shots were fired, resulting in three deaths. MISCA intervened to restore calm.
Armed Anti-Balaka entered a home at night, demanded money from the family and ransacked the house. They tied the husband up, threatened to kill the wife, and fired shots to scare the neighbours.
Between 14th and 17th of June, 10 bodies bearing signs of torture were pulled from the Ouaka river. Perpetrators and time and location of deaths currently unknown.
Students of the University of Bangui struck to demand payment of their scholarships. They used stones and scrap vehicles to barricade the roads. The barricades were removed by midday.
Two people were surrounded by a group of individuals from the Cameroonian district of Bangui, who killed them.

At least 21 people killed, 30 wounded and 127 homes burned in clashes between ex-Seleka, backed by armed Fulani, and a local militia over 9-10 June in Lawi village. Among the 21 killed, two were hostages taken by the Seleka and killed publicly upon the militias return in Bambari on the first day of fighting. Angry residents confronted the militiamen, who threw a grenade to disperse the crowd, injuring at least three.

At least 21 people killed, 30 wounded and 127 homes burned in clashes between ex-Seleka, backed by armed Fulani, and a local militia over 9-10 June in Lawi village. Among the 21 killed, two were hostages taken by the Seleka and killed publicly upon the militias return in Bambari on the first day of fighting. Angry residents confronted the militiamen, who threw a grenade to disperse the crowd, injuring at least three.

Angry residents confronted the militiamen, who threw a grenade to disperse the crowd, injuring at least three.
Villagers in Liwa killed two Muslim men on a motorcycle.
Lami village was burned by gunmen. No official report released yet, but sources say 43 killed and 100 wounded. Some residents claim that Alkamba Mbororo herders are responsible.

assoc_actor_2: Police Forces of the Central African Republic (2003-2013)
notes: A former policeman and his son were killed in their home by armed men.

actor1: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: An 18-hour curfew is imposed by MISCA in Carnot

assoc_actor_2: Military Forces of the Central African Republic (2014-2016)
notes: One person was killed and a dozen injured after an attack where two grenades were thrown at a nigh club in the 2nd arrondissement of Bangui. The victim was a member of FACA.
French Defence Ministry reports fighting between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka near Bambari.

Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka in Boyo, 45km from Bambari, in response to the Anti-Balaka attack on the Muslim population. One death on the side of ex-Seleka and 18 deaths among the Anti-Balaka.
Anti-Balaka attack the Muslim population of Boyo, 45km from Bambari.

A Cameroonian truck driver was killed by angry residents, despite the presence of a MISCA escort, after he was involved in an accident which resulted in the death of another person and the severe injury of another.
Anti-Balaka forces carried out a rape in the village of Wapo, situated 9km from Berberati.

On 4 June 2014, two people were killed by extra-judicial execution by Anti-Balaka elements in Popoto, Berberati. A crowd of residents was said to have assisted in the killings. At least one of the victims was reportedly killed for involvement in witchcraft.
Ex-Seleka attack Bakala village. Casualties unknown.
Seven people, including two village leaders and a pastor, killed after ex-Seleka attack Bobala village. They accused them of being Anti-Balaka.
Ex-Seleka attack Yabe village, outside of Bambari. Casualties unknown.
Several Muslims from Pk5 received gunshot wounds.
Anti-Balaka reported to have used force to kidnap civilians in Bangui and held them for ransom.
Three persons were injured in a grenade attack perpetrated by an attack in a Muslim community. Muslim leaders denounced the attack but the anti-balaka movement has denied any involvement in this act.

assoc_actor_2: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Aid Workers (Central African Republic); Health Workers (Central African Republic)
notes: Medecins Sans Frontieres (MSF) withdrew some of its staff from Ndele following an attack against its house located there. No fatalities.
Part of the population of Mboki attacked a car and the premises of the NGO Coopi, plundering and destroying the building. Coopi has suspended its activities following this.

On 1 June 2014, it was reported that Anti-Balaka tortured and killed a man accused of practising witchcraft in Berberati. Anti-Balaka denied involvement, and claimed that it was the family and community that killed him.
The Muslim community of Km5 marched against the proposed disarmament of Muslims in the neighbourhood, as they fear attacks by Anti-Balaka.

actor2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: Anti-government protests held by armed demonstrators who shot at Sangaris troops and tried to force their way into a MISCA base. MISCA responded by returning fire, killing three.

Residents took to the streets in Fatima, Petevo, Lakouanga and Bimbo to show discontent for the inability of the government and international forces to restore security in the country. They erected barricades and cause traffic to come to a standstill.

Residents took to the streets in Fatima, Petevo, Lakouanga and Bimbo to show discontent for the inability of the government and international forces to restore security in the country. They erected barricades and cause traffic to come to a standstill.

Two members of Anti-Balaka had a disagreement over whether a barricade should be dismantled or not. As a result, one shot the other, killing him.
A 60 year old man was buried alive because he was suspected by the people of his district to be responsible for the deaths of two his own children by witchcraft.

Residents took to the streets in Fatima, Petevo, Lakouanga and Bimbo to show discontent for the inability of the government and international forces to restore security in the country. They erected barricades and cause traffic to come to a standstill.

People erect barricades and burn tyres in Bea-Rex, by the UN roundabout, Benz-Vi and Fouh to express their anger at the recent attack on the Church of Our Lady of Fatima. In PK-3, they marched brandishing Anti-Burundian placards.

actor1: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: Warning shots fired by MISCA are heard in Bangui in the aftermath of the attack on the Church of Our Lady of Fatima.
Youths protested in PK-3, brandishing Anti-Burundian placards, as they feel that the Burundian contingent of MISCA failed to protect civilians attacked in the Church of Our Lady of Fatima.
A group of Christian youths destroyed one of the last mosques in Bangui.

A 45 year old man was attacked on his way to Bria by an unidentified armed group. The victim was travelling to the market in Bria; other market sellers in Ndele have since announced they will not travel.

assoc_actor_2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: Anti-Balaka try to enter Pk5 by force, clashing with young Muslims who try to defend the area, backed by MISCA.
A man was killed while hunting about 20km from Kabo. Fulani are blamed.

assoc_actor_2: Christian Group (Central African Republic); Refugees/IDPs (Central African Republic)
notes: At least 49 dead (including a priest and 38 people who had been abducted), and dozens wounded when armed men entered the Church of Our Lady of Fatima as people were gathered inside for a religious ceremony. They opened fire and threw grenades. The grounds of this church housed 5,000 IDPs, many of whom have since fled. Ex-Seleka blamed for attack, but authorities admit they are not certain. Some claim that armed youth from Km5 are responsible for the attack.
Armed youths from Km5 shoot towards an IDP camp at Saint Joseph of Moukassa parish. A twelve year old child is killed and 12 Muslims are injured.
A 30 year old Muslim trader was stabbed to death by young Muslims when he went to deliver livestock to customers.
A 20 year old-man was kidnapped by a group of young Muslims when he went to buy goods in Km5. The attackers spoke with his mother on the phone, to ask her to collect his body.

assoc_actor_1: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
assoc_actor_2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: Clashes between Anti-Balaka and suspected Muslim militia near Fondo and Mbairi neighborhoods following the killing and maiming of three Muslims the day before in Bangui. MISCA reportedly intervened to disperse the groups but shots and grenades fired throughout the day.
MISCA report clashes between young Muslims and Anti-Balaka, following the triple murder of three Muslims.
Three young Muslims were killed and maimed while traveling to a soccer game that was organised to reconcile Muslims and Christians. Their heads, genitals and hearts were removed.
People of Carnot hold a peaceful march to protest against the presence of MISCA and to call for reconciliation and peace.
Clashes between ex-Seleka and Sangaris. No deaths reported.

actor2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: Clashes continue between Anti-Balaka and MISCA following the lynching of a Muslim man. Five killed and many injured between 23rd and 24th of May 2014 due to these clashes.

actor2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: Clashes between MISCA and Anti-Balaka. Five killed and many injured between 23rd and 24th of May 2014 due to these clashes.

assoc_actor_2: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)
notes: Anti-Balaka lynch a Muslim man to death. MISCA try to intervene in the lynching by firing warning shots.
A march was organised by some Muslims, backed by ex-Seleka, to protest against the presence of Sangaris in the area. They fired shots into the air.
A Ndeke-Luka journalist was attacked by ex-Seleka while he was working.

At least one person killed when Sangaris fire on locals who are protesting against the disarmament of ex-Seleka. They fear that if ex-Seleka are disarmed, Anti-Balaka will attack. No reports of violent activity on the side of the protesters.
Ex-Seleka resist disarmament by Sangaris. Shots were exchanged. Two deaths reported.
The death of a person shot by Sangaris angered the the people of Bambari who, armed with bows, arrows and machetes, set fire to Sangaris barricades.
Protesters, supported by ex-Seleka, protested against state activities in the area. They closed the doors of the town hall, causing the suspension of activities.
Ex-Seleka storm Kemngo Yeye village, firing in the air and looting homes. A pregnant woman was beaten and a man was shot in the foot.

source: Radio Ndeke Luka; RCA (Central African Republic)
notes: A woman accused of being a witch is killed by Anti-Balaka in Danzito village. On the same day, a pregnant woman and her baby were killed by Anti-Balaka in Poto Poto neighborhood of Bangui as they attempted to loot a shop they believed belonged to her uncle, taking a youth hostage during the incident. [women targeted: accused of witchcraft/sorcery][women targeted: relatives of targeted groups or persons]

A convoy of ex-Seleka arrive in Dekoa. Gunfire is heard, and there are reports of the armed men forcing women to strip in order to make them to hand over food and NFIs distributed through humanitarian channels.

assoc_actor_2: ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross and Red Crescent; Health Workers (Central African Republic)
notes: ICRC has suspended activities outside of urban areas in Central and Nord-East parts of country due to attacks on two vehicles in Yambala village by gunmen on 17 May.
A group of armed men, who came from Chad, kidnapped four people and killed the head of the health centre in Markounda. The kidnapped are believed to have been taken to Chad.

At least three people were killed in attacks between 14th and 16th May 2014 in two villages located less than 10 km from Batangafo by armed Fulani. The attackers also wounded five other people, and two cases of rape of women reported. The violence was followed by looting.

At least three people were killed in attacks between 14th and 16th May 2014 in two villages located less than 10 km from Batangafo by armed Fulani. The attackers also wounded five other people, and two cases of rape of women reported. The violence was followed by looting.
Four members of a Fulani family were killed by Anti-Balaka, and another was injured.
While working in the fields, a man was killed by Fulani herders and his wife beaten in Bafio village, 7km from Batangafo.
Unidentified armed men arrived in Markounda and opened fire on residents, killing 22 people and wounding many.
In response to the Anti-Balaka attack on Fulani civilians in Awatche, ex-Seleka raid the village, fire shots, and burn two houses.
Clashes between Anti-Balaka and ex-Seleka near Dekoa. 10 people dead and many wounded, most of them civilians.

Following the clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka near Dekoa, ex-Seleka members carried out reprisal attacks in villages between Dekoa and Kaga Bandoro. Some villagers were shot dead or wounded while looting took place.
Unidentified armed man shoots and kills a twelve year old Muslim girls. A six year old and a baby were also injured in the shootings.

At least three people were killed in attacks between 14th and 16th May 2014 in two villages located less than 10 km from Batangafo by armed Fulani. The attackers also wounded five other people, and two cases of rape of women reported. The violence was followed by looting.
Ex-Seleka attack Anti-Balaka, resulting in clashes between the two groups. Several deaths reported (exact death toll currently unknown), and two Anti-Balaka taken hostage by ex-Seleka.
A taxi driver was beaten by Anti-Balaka.
Kouango now under the control of ex-Seleka after they entered the area and clashed with Anti-Balaka.

Arrests: More than a hundred students of the ecole Normale des Instituteurs (ENI) were arrested by ex-Seleka and taken to prison. They were released some hours later following the intervention of the Director of ENI.
Gunmen abducted a man in Kaga Bandoro - his body was found the following day. Another woman was killed in Ngoulikpa village by unknown gunmen. Dozens of cases of lootings also reported.
Ex-Seleka attack the village of Lakandjia. Two deaths and many houses burned.

Ex-Seleka and Peul ambushed an Anti-Balaka vehicle. At least ten combatants died in the ensuing clash, including four Anti-Balaka and six ex-Seleka and Peul. French journalist Camille Lepage, who was on assignment with the Anti-Balaka, was also killed.
In retaliation to the killing of a Fulani chief by villagers, ex-Seleka attack Yamaka, resulting in seven dead, many wounded and coffee plantations burned.
Fighting among Anti-Balaka soldiers results in the deaths of two combatants.
In retaliation to the killing of a Fulani chief by villagers, ex-Seleka attack Goussima, resulting in 66 dead, many wounded, and hundreds of homes and coffee plantations burned.
Ex-Seleka stab a man at an illegal road block when he did not have the money to pay the fine imposed.
Ex-Seleka announce autonomous government in the northern region around Ndele.
Ex-Seleka announce Joseph Zoundeko as their new military leader in a bid to unite the rebel group.
Armed men, similar to ex-Seleka and armed Fulani, attacked Dissikou. They captured 13 people in a house, barricaded the exits, and set the house alight, killing the captives.
Villagers accuse a Fulani chief of being complicit with ex-Seleka and kill him.

assoc_actor_1: UJCA: Union of Central African Journalists
notes: A news blackout day was staged, organised by the Union of Central African Journalists (UJCA), during which newspapers were not for sale and radios and TVs did not broadcast any news, to denounce the recent killings of two journalists. The UJCA staged a demonstration in Bangui for this.

assoc_actor_1: MISCA: African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (2013-2014)

Anti-Balaka attacked ex-Seleka, resulting in clashes that killed 13 people (including 11 Anti-Balaka and two civilians), injured many others and displaced nearly 13,000 people in Kaga Bandoro. Many homes were also burned and looted.
Armed men attack the village of Gousseyama, causing people to flee.
Armed men attack the village of Lakandjia, causing people to flee.
French troops are attacked by armed men on motorbikes. They responded, resulting in the deaths of several of the attackers. No deaths on the French side. Ex-Seleka are blamed for the attack.
One person was killed when armed men threw a grenade at his home.
Eight pushers and five traders were beaten by Anti-Balaka.
Four people were found dead and tied up, with gunshot and torture wounds.

Report of three additional people killed in Bangui on 29 April by unknown gunmen in Sarah area.

Anti-Balaka & ex-Seleka clashed in Grimari. The number of dead is unknown.

Two civilians were killed and six others wounded when Anti-Balaka ambushed a convoy of Muslim Peuls fleeing violence in Bangui. MISCA troops returned fire on the armed men but were unable to catch them.

'Three INGO staff members were killed by armed ex-Seleka members during a meeting with community leaders to discuss medical care and access. The ex-Seleka proceeded to rob the office. Fifteen other individuals, all local chiefs, were killed as well.'

'One national INGO aid worker was assaulted in Bangui while on his way home after work. He later died in the hospital as a result of his injuries.'
The LRA opened fire on a vehicle of civilians. They killed one and kidnapped another, who was released some hours later.

Anti-Balaka attacked the Km5 area, but met resistance from a self-defense group. Two bodies were seen after this attack.
Armed Fulani from Chad attack Bemal village - dozens of persons were killed, several others wounded, and houses burned.
A soldier & his wife were killed in Bazanga

The people of Boali took to the streets to protest against a rumoured replacement of the Congolese MISCA troops by the Burundian contingent.
Ex-Seleka attacked the town of Botto. Exact death toll currently unknown, but multiple reports of dead bodies on the street.

After being fired upon after intervening in clashes between ex-Seleka and Anti-Balaka, Sangaris chased down the Anti-Balaka, killing several of them. Witnesses say that most of those killed were armed, but three did not appear to be.

A priest was killed by gunmen believed to be Fulani and ex-Seleka who opened fire on him while he was in traffic on a motorcycle. They then mutilated his body.

Ex-Seleka stormed the hospital in Bambari, threatening the staff and telling them not to treat anyone with injuries from the incidents that recently occurred in Grimari.
Armed men, suspected to be ex-Seleka, attacked Libala village, 55km from Gamboula, killing three and wounding others.

A member of ex-Seleka opened fire in the city, creating panic among the population after he was accused by young people of having killed a member of the Central African Armed Forces.
